Also [Mapun](LanguageTable#cldf:19176) _maat_ ‘evil; badness’, _mag-maat_ ‘to do bad; to have bad intentions’, _ka-maat-an_ ‘dislike something’ (lit. ‘be affected by the badness of something’), [Tausug](LanguageTable#cldf:18831) _kaat_ ‘(for a person) to go wrong, do things that are considered bad; (for someone’s behavior) to become bad’, [Murung](LanguageTable#cldf:872) _jeʔet_ ‘bad, [Iban](LanguageTable#cldf:276) _jaiʔ_ ‘bad, spoilt, broken, out of order, no more use’, [Jarai](LanguageTable#cldf:284) _sat_ ‘bad’, [Toba Batak](LanguageTable#cldf:427) _jahat_ ‘bad; vulgar’, [Lamaholot](LanguageTable#cldf:19031) _daʔ_ ‘bad’, [Toqabaqita](LanguageTable#cldf:19197) _taʔaa_ ‘be bad, no good; general term for expressing negative evaluation’.
Also [Kayan (Uma Juman)](LanguageTable#cldf:438) _jaʔək_, [Bintulu](LanguageTable#cldf:242) _jaʔəs_ ‘bad, evil’.

Also [Itawis](LanguageTable#cldf:648) _dahét_ ‘stitch’, _mad-dahét_ ‘to sew’, [Jarai](LanguageTable#cldf:284) _jhik_ ‘to sew’, [Muna](LanguageTable#cldf:350) _dhai_ ‘sew an ornamental seam (to trouser legs; a practice in former times)’, [Molima](LanguageTable#cldf:18975) _saila_ ‘to sew, make nets’.
[Dempwolff (1934-38)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) reconstructed doublets *_zaraŋaw_, *_zariŋaw_.

Also [Malay](LanguageTable#cldf:326) _jaliŋ_ ‘barrier net (said to be rare)’.  In addition, [Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) included [Tagalog](LanguageTable#cldf:423) _dáliŋ_ ~ _dálin_ ‘fastening; binding for bamboo floors’, but the divergent semantics raises questions about whether this form is cognate.  This comparison, which was first proposed by [Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) in a somewhat more restricted form, remains problematic.  I assume that [Maori](LanguageTable#cldf:330) _tari_ shows the ‘third palatal reflex’ found in a number of other forms, but the connection of Oceanic forms to those in western Indonesia may be due to chance.

Also [Kavalan](LanguageTable#cldf:293) _Rami_ ‘rice straw’, [Bunun](LanguageTable#cldf:250) _dumali_ (< met.) ‘millet straw’, [Tagalog](LanguageTable#cldf:423) _dayámi_ ‘straw; hay; dried rice or grain stalks used as fodder for cattle’ ([Kapampangan](LanguageTable#cldf:291) loan), [Binukid](LanguageTable#cldf:19012) _lagami_ ‘stalk that is left after the grain or sugarcane has been harvested; straw’, [Bare'e](LanguageTable#cldf:236) _deami_ ‘rice stubble; fallow ricefield’.  


The basic referent of this term appears to have been that part of the rice stalk that remains in the field after the harvest (to fertilize the soil for the next planting).  In at least two widely-separated languages ([Old Javanese](LanguageTable#cldf:660) and [Tontemboan](LanguageTable#cldf:19052)) this word also refers to a flute made from a rice stalk, and in parts of northern Sulawesi the meaning has shifted from the stalks of the planted rice left after the harvest to the invasive weeds and brush that sprouts in a newly fallow field.

Also [Tagalog](LanguageTable#cldf:423) _dálaŋ_ 'sparseness; scarcity; infrequency'.  [Dempwolff (1934-38)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) has *_zaraŋ_ ‘seldom; scarce’.  The Bisaya form shows secondary prenasalization of _g_ from *_R_.

Also [Puyuma](LanguageTable#cldf:386) _daum_ ‘sewing needle’ (< [Paiwan](LanguageTable#cldf:370)), [Agta (Dupaningan)](LanguageTable#cldf:19194) _dagum_ ‘needle’ (< [Ilokano](LanguageTable#cldf:279)), [Bontok](LanguageTable#cldf:246) _dágom_ ‘needle’, [Ibaloy](LanguageTable#cldf:19182) _shaKom_ ‘needle (as for sewing, injection)’, [Pangasinan](LanguageTable#cldf:920) _dágom_ ‘needle’, [Tagalog](LanguageTable#cldf:423) _ka-rayom_ ‘needle’ (< [Kapampangan](LanguageTable#cldf:291)), [Hanunóo](LanguageTable#cldf:273) _dágum_ (< a Bisayan source?), [Tausug](LanguageTable#cldf:18831) _jawm_ ‘a needle; any needle-like object, as a compass needle or the hands of a watch’ (< [Malay](LanguageTable#cldf:326)), [Bare'e](LanguageTable#cldf:236) _jaru_ ‘European fabric needle (< [Malay](LanguageTable#cldf:326) or [Buginese](LanguageTable#cldf:239)).  [Manggarai](LanguageTable#cldf:816) _jaruŋ_ may be a [Makassarese](LanguageTable#cldf:325) loan.
Also [Malagasy (Provincial)](LanguageTable#cldf:781) _javanjavana_ ‘illumination’.

[Old Javanese](LanguageTable#cldf:660) _jawa_, after which the island of Java may have been named, is sometimes thought to be a loan from Sanskrit _yawa_ ‘barley’, a word that reportedly derives from the more general term ‘grain’ attested in both Avestan and Sanskrit ([Buck 1949: 513](Source#cldf:buck1949)).  Adopting this interpretation requires the assumption that Sanskrit _yawa_ ‘barley’ was borrowed as pre-Javanese _jawa_ ‘millet’ within the past two millennia, as the early Indian name for Java was Yawadwipa, presumably because millet was widely cultivated on Java at that time (barley is not a native Southeast Asian crop --- see the doubts expressed in the gloss of Old Javanese jawa).  


This putative loanword then spread northward with substitution of _d_ for _j_ in languages that lacked palatals, presumably replacing whatever term applied to the type of millet that this word represented.  One possible scenario, then, is that _jawa_ > _dawa_ replaced reflexes of *_beCeŋ_ ‘foxtail millet: _Setaria italica_’.  However, the specific application of reflexes of *_zawa_ to foxtail millet in southern Taiwan and much of the central Philippines (but not in intervening areas) argues against this interpretation and in favor of *_zawa_ as a [PAn](LanguageTable#cldf:PAN) term that has been lost over wide areas but retained in scattered pockets in its original meaning.  Various references ([Aklanon](LanguageTable#cldf:226), [Cebuano](LanguageTable#cldf:252), [Agutaynen](LanguageTable#cldf:19189), [Yakan](LanguageTable#cldf:1129), [Iban](LanguageTable#cldf:276)) suggest that millet was secondary to rice as a daily staple in virtually all language groups, a factor that may have played a role in the far more robust attestation for terms like *_pajay_ or *_beRas_ as compared with *_beCeŋ_, or *_zawa_.
[Miri](LanguageTable#cldf:338) _jukat_ is assumed to be a _u_ ablaut form of an unrecorded base **_jəkat_.
Possibly a product of convergence.

Description: a cereal grass with edible seeds that are also used as beads, Job’s tears: Coix lachryma-jobi L.
Comment: Also [Malay](LanguageTable#cldf:326) _henjelay_ ‘millet’, [Old Javanese](LanguageTable#cldf:660) _jahəli_ ~ _jahli_ ~ _jali_ ‘a kind of millet: _Eleusine coracana_’, [Javanese](LanguageTable#cldf:285) _jali_ ‘a plant that produces corn-like (barley-like) kernels’, [Balinese](LanguageTable#cldf:235) _jali-jali_ ‘a species of plant’.

Also [Manobo (Western Bukidnon)](LanguageTable#cldf:819) _siliŋ_ ‘cross-eyed’, [Old Javanese](LanguageTable#cldf:660) _jilak_ ‘partial eye defect (cross-eyed?)’, [Wolio](LanguageTable#cldf:1124) _jilo_ ‘cross-eyed, squint’, [Rotuman](LanguageTable#cldf:394) _jila_ ‘squint, be crossed (eyes)’.
Also [Toba Batak](LanguageTable#cldf:427) _gomak_ ‘grasp something, take a handful’, [Mongondow](LanguageTable#cldf:245) _domok_ ‘catch, grasp, seize; fight, come to blows or grips’.

Description: pinch, take up with the fingers
Comment: [Uma](LanguageTable#cldf:19170) _jopiʔ_ may be a [Kulawi](LanguageTable#cldf:710) loan.  With root *[-pit](root-acd-r_p.htm#-pit(or*-peclit?)) (or *_peqit_?) ‘press, squeeze together; narrow’.

Description: hurt, frightened, or discouraged by previous bad experience
Comment:
Also [Tagalog](LanguageTable#cldf:423) _daláʔ_ ‘wary, cautious or scared because of previous painful, unpleasant, unfortunate or unsatisfactory experience’, _ma-daláʔ_, _dalaʔ-ín_ ‘to have an unpleasant experience caused by the attitude of others or by other circumstances; to be taught by painful experience (in consequence of which one is wary about returning to a certain place)’, [Cebuano](LanguageTable#cldf:252) _dulá_ ‘for animals to be shy and not allow anyone to approach them’,  [Mapun](LanguageTable#cldf:19176) _dallaʔ_ ‘to give up doing something (because of having a bad or painful experience; to begin to give up’, _dallaʔ-un_ ‘cause someone to give up doing something’.  


It is unclear whether the [Tagalog](LanguageTable#cldf:423) and [Mapun](LanguageTable#cldf:19176) forms justify a doublet *_zeraq_, but this seems doubtful, since the expected [Tagalog](LanguageTable#cldf:423) reflex of such a form would be **__diláʔ__.  Rather, it seems more likely that forms such as those listed in this note are loanwords from [Malay](LanguageTable#cldf:326).  The same cannot be said, however, for [Manobo (Western Bukidnon)](LanguageTable#cldf:819) _deǥa_, and so the reconstruction stands despite the questionable nature of some of its members.
Also [Toba Batak](LanguageTable#cldf:427) jorat ‘noose trap for catching animals’ (< [Malay](LanguageTable#cldf:326)).
The Oceanic members of this comparison are taken from [Ross (2008:232)](Source#cldf:rosspawleyandosmond2008).

Description: touching or joined along the length
Comment: With root [*-kit₂ ](root-acd-r_k.htm#-kit₂)‘join along the length’.
[Iban](LanguageTable#cldf:276) _jərat_ ‘running noose, snare’ is assumed to be a [Malay](LanguageTable#cldf:326) loan.

Description: vine from which poison is obtained

Comment: Also [Bintulu](LanguageTable#cldf:242) _mən-duʔ_ ‘to bathe’. [Mills (1975:684)](Source#cldf:mills1975) posits [Proto-South Sulawesi](LanguageTable#cldf:19092) *_dio(C(?))_, ‘bathe’, which he associates with [PAn](LanguageTable#cldf:PAN) *_DiRuq_ or *_DiRus_, with unexplained loss of *_R_.
Also [Malay](LanguageTable#cldf:326) _jijék_, _cicék_ ‘disgust’, [Javanese](LanguageTable#cldf:285) _jijiːk_ ‘revolted, disgusted’.

[Milke (1961:170, 173)](Source#cldf:milke1961) compares the [Sa'a](LanguageTable#cldf:18945) word with [Fijian](LanguageTable#cldf:266) _sisiva_ ‘jealous’, [Tongan](LanguageTable#cldf:434) _hihihihi_ ‘gnash the teeth’, [Samoan](LanguageTable#cldf:401) _ma-sisi_ ‘term of abuse’. However, his source for [Tongan](LanguageTable#cldf:434) ([Churchward 1959](Source#cldf:churchward1959)) does not list _hihihihi_ in the stated meaning, and [Pratt's (1984)](Source#cldf:pratt1984) _masisi_ ‘the piece of wood used in operating for _tafao_ (circumcision), used reproachfully’ presents both formal and semantic problems, thus effectively invalidating the earlier comparison.

[Milke (1961:170, 173)](Source#cldf:milke1961) compares the [Sa'a](LanguageTable#cldf:18945) word with [Fijian](LanguageTable#cldf:266) _sisiva_ ‘jealous’, [Tongan](LanguageTable#cldf:434) _hihihihi_ ‘gnash the teeth’, [Samoan](LanguageTable#cldf:401) _ma-sisi_ ‘term of abuse’. However, his source for [Tongan](LanguageTable#cldf:434) ([Churchward 1959](Source#cldf:churchward1959)) does not list _hihihihi_ in the stated meaning, and [Pratt's (1984)](Source#cldf:pratt1984) _masisi_ ‘the piece of wood used in operating for _tafao_ (circumcision), used reproachfully’ presents both formal and semantic problems, thus effectively invalidating the earlier comparison.
Also [Bikol](LanguageTable#cldf:244) _dúʔot_ ‘grass, lawn, weed’.

Also [Malay](LanguageTable#cldf:326) _dahulu_, _dulu_ ‘before; in advance of; ahead’.  Sasak _Ɂ_ in this form is unexplained, but given the sporadic and often non-corresponding occurence of final glottal closure in languages such as [Iban](LanguageTable#cldf:276) and [Sasak](LanguageTable#cldf:404), the final consonant in this form cannot be reconstructed with any confidence.

Also [Javanese](LanguageTable#cldf:285) _juŋkruk_ ‘sit with bowed head’, [Makassarese](LanguageTable#cldf:325) _dukku_ ‘bend over, bow, duck down; crouch down to hide.  With root [*-kuk₁](root-acd-r_k.htm#-kuk₁) ‘bent, crooked’.  Possibly a chance resemblance made more similar through sharing a common monosyllabic root.

Also [Maranao](LanguageTable#cldf:331) _pidoro_ ‘corner, form’ (< [Malay](LanguageTable#cldf:326)?), [Mansaka](LanguageTable#cldf:825) _kadogoŋan_ ‘corner (as of house), [Minangkabau](LanguageTable#cldf:337) _pinjuru_ ‘corner; section, quarter’.  This term may have had a more precise meaning than that given here.

Also [Javanese](LanguageTable#cldf:285) _juruh_ sweet thick syrup or sauce, usually made of coconut sugar, [Balinese](LanguageTable#cldf:235) _juruh_ syrup.  The exact meaning of this term is hard to pin down.  It evidently referred to naturally occurring liquids that are more viscous than water, as juices of fruits, coconut water and the like, as well as broths or soups that are produced by cooking.
__language__Isneg__ _ubād_ 'untie, unbind, let loose' (expected **_ubag_) suggests that __language__Aklanon__ _húbad_ may not contain the root *_-baj_.
__language__Bontok__ _teŋbaw_, __language__Maranao__ _tebao_ may belong to a single cognate set.
__language__Palawan Batak__ _lubaʔo_ 'shallow' suggests *_-baqu_.
__language__PWMP__ *_lebek_ fits equally well under *_-bek₂_.  __language__Ifugaw__ _imbók_ may be cognate with __language__Tagalog__ _hibík_.

__language__PAn__ *_bi(R)biR_, __language__Kavalan__ _tu:bíl_ 'lip' probably do not contain *_-bir_ (cf. [Blust 1980:53ff](Source#cldf:blust1980)). Also cp. __language__Balinese__ _simpir_ 'edge, margin, rim'.

Description: heap, pile, cover with earth; collect, assemble
rice gruel; rice porridge; to mix
Comment: Also __language__Bintulu__ _avud_ 'porridge of sago pearls boiled with coconut meat', __language__Maranao__ _kambor_ 'stir, mix', __language__Manobo (Western Bukidnon)__ _rembur_ 'to mix different kinds of seed together', __language__Maranao__ _sambor_ 'mix', __language__Maranao__ _sembor_ 'mix, mixture', __language__Isneg__ _tambúr_ 'mix shredded coconut meat with _bási_ (rum)', with root candidate *_-bur_.
Also __language__Balinese__ _burbur_ 'scatter, throw down in confusion'.
Also __language__Mongondow__ _lobog_ 'turbid, murky'.
[Marsh (1977:95)](Source#cldf:marsh1977) also cites "__language__Proto-Favorlang-Pazeh-Saisiat__" *_t₂abus_ 'all', but the supporting evidence that he cites is open to question.

Description: muddy; sound of walking in mud
Comment: Also __language__Malay (Jakarta)__ _bacek_ 'wet, soft, become waterlogged'; __language__Sundanese__ _1+c+k_ 'muddy', with root candidate *_-cek_.
Also __language__Ilokano__ _derrém_ 'to dim, of the sun, the light of a candle, etc.'.
Also __language__Casiguran Dumagat__ _ilemlem_ 'of a chicken, to sit on its eggs', __language__Kayan__ _selem_ 'to think within oneself'.

__language__Bikol__ _badát_ should be **_badot_. I assume that it shows assimilation of the last vowel to the first. The variant _budát_ 'full and unable to eat any more' is assumed to show metathesis of the vowels.
Also __language__Ujir__ _huluk_ 'spoon, ladle'.
__language__Maranao__ _podoŋ_ and __language__Fijian__ _pu(u)ru_ may belong to a single cognate set.
Also __language__Balinese__ _ceket_ 'sensitive, short-tempered'.

Also __language__Kadazan Dusun__ _hiŋkib_ 'open slightly', __language__Aklanon__ _tukifb_ 'open up a little (as a window)'. __language__Tagalog__ _hikafb_ next to _higafb_ 'yawn' may show contamination from *_-kab_.

__language__Malay__ _cekaŋ_, _jeŋkaŋ_ may contain a reflex of *_-keŋ_ 'cramps, stiffening of the limbs'. __language__Jakartanese (Betawi)__ _jeŋkaŋ_ 'prostrate; dead', however, unambiguously indicates *_-kaŋ_.
Also __language__Dairi-Pakpak Batak__ _beka_ 'split in two', __language__Karo Batak__, __language__Dairi-Pakpak Batak__ _taka_ 'split, cleave' (both < *_-ka_).
Perhaps also __language__Karo Batak__ _laŋkem_ 'lie on the stomach', __language__Kayan__ _tukem_ 'facing downwards', both of which are presently assigned to *_-keb₂_.
__language__Manobo (Western Bukidnon)__ _ki?it_ 'bite off something with the front teeth' suggests a root *_-kigit_.

Description: sound of a sob, cackle, etc.

Comment: Also __language__Casiguran Dumagat__ _ilép_ 'reflect (of something shiny)', __language__Ilokano__ _sírap_ 'dazzle'.
Also __language__Old Javanese__ _telā_ 'cleft, crevice, crack, narrow opening'.
Also __language__Isneg__ _inírat_ 'the scar left on a tree when a nest of bees has been removed from it'.
Also cp. __language__Maranao__ _galoŋ_ 'nose ring'.
Also __language__Iban__ _rumoh_ 'shatter, (of food) crumble'.
Also __language__Bikol__ _ignít_ 'stretch something'.
Also __language__Cebuano__ _ŋaŋhá_ 'be open-mouthed with sudden surprise'.

The final consonant in __language__Javanese__ _deŋak_, _ḍeŋak_ 'facing upward, craning the neck', _laŋak_ '(puppet with an) upturned gaze', and _iŋakuŋak_ 'crane the neck in an effort to see' can only reflect *_k_. Since __language__Malay__ and __language__Sasak__ _-k_ reflect both *_-g_ and *_-k_ it is possible that the forms cited from these languages contain a root *_-ŋak_, and are not to be compared directly with the Philippine material.
Also __language__PMP__ *_ŋurut_ 'growl, whine'
__language__Proto-Micronesian__ _*faŋus-_ may be cognate with __language__Sundanese__ _baŋus_, but for the present I treat the resemblance as a product of chance convergence.
Also __language__Balinese__ _sepeg_ 'chop violently at, hew'.

Description: decay, crumble; sound of breaking; powder

Comment: Also __language__Tiruray__ _barek_ 'the spots on an eel'.
__language__Gorontalo__ _pilito_ may contain a reflex of *_-ris₂_ 'scratch a line'.

__language__Malay__ _derut_ 'dull scraping sound', _garut_ 'scraping against one another', _gerut_ 'any dull scraping sound', _karut_ 'rasp', _sarut_ 'scraping up against; grating against' and the like appear to reflect prototypes with *_-t_; __language__Bikol__ _súrod_ 'to harrow' reflects *_sujud_.

Description: insert, stick into a soft surface
Comment: Also __language__PAn__ *_pacek_ drive in (a nail, post)', __language__Malay__ _cacak_ 'planting upright, embedding', with root candidate *_-cek_. __language__PMP__ *_pusek_ is reconstructed erroneously as *_pucek_ in [Blust (1986)](Source#cldf:blust1986).
Also __language__PMP__ *_cukcuk_ 'skewer'.

Description: sever, rip, cut through; short cut
Comment: __language__Cebuano__ _baktás_ may reflect earlier *_bagtás_, with voice assimilation.
Also __language__Cebuano__ _hútik_ 'be all mud; for an area to turn to mud', __language__Maranao__ _potik_ 'mud; paddy'.
Also __language__Ilokano__ _weŋweŋ_ 'a buzzing sound produced in the ear', _yeŋyeŋ_ 'bothered, confused, bewildered, flurried (with noise)'.
Also __language__Bontok__ _téeŋ_ 'stare at'.
Also __language__Toba Batak__ _binsil_ 'clitoris'.
Possibly identical to *_-tuk₁_.
Due to the predictability of a transitional glide, _-wit_ following *_u_ is written _-it_.
__language__Toba Batak__ _irjak_ points to *_-zak_, but __language__Javanese__ _pidak_ to *_-Zak_.
Also__language__ PMP__ *_tezek_ 'stand erect; upright (posts)'.

__language__Malay__ _bəlisah_ points to a proto-form with *_-q_, which __language__Cebuano__ _balísa_ supports a similar form with final vowel.  __language__Malay__ _gəlisah_ presumably is a secondary development from earlier _bəlisah_.

Despite the striking similarity of these forms a reconstruction is impossible.  In both languages the last four segments could reflect either *_iwal_ or *_iwaR_. However, __language__Saisiyat__ _s-_ can reflect only __language__PAn__ *_C-_, which became __language__Kavalan__ _t-_, and __language__Kavalan__ _s-_ can reflect only __language__PAn__ *_s_ or *_S_, which became __language__Saisiyat__ _h_ and _ʃ_ respectively, leaving the proto-form in limbo, despite the near certainty that it points to a phonetically similar form in __language__PAn__.
__language__Manobo (Western Bukidnon)__ _endud_ reflects *_endud_ or *_enduD;_ __language__Malay__ _undur_ reflects *_unduD_, *_undur_, or *_unduR_.
The forms in northern Luzon reflect *_baRat_, while __language__Tanjong__ and __language__Kejaman__ _balat_ can only come from *_balat_, and the remaining forms from *_balak_.
The __language__Isneg__ form points to *_luRut_ or *_lugut_, which the __language__Kayan__ form can reflect only *_lukut_.
According to [Wilkinson (1959)](Source#cldf:wilkinson1959) __language__Malay__ _basat_ is of Chinese origin, although this remains to be established.

[Osmond (2011:401)](Source#cldf:osmond2011) uses these and other non-corresponding forms to posit __language__POc__ *_tabuRuRu_ ‘kind of beetle’.  While there clearly is a historical connection between these forms, the sound correspondences fail to agree, and a reconstruction is thus impossible on the basis of known evidence.

Description: biting: hold by biting carry in the mouth

Comment: The __language__Thao__ and __language__Favorlang/Babuza__ words are cognate, but point to a lower-order proto-language, __language__Proto-Western Plains__ *_mumu_.
The last vowel of the Admiralty forms (__language__Wuvulu__, __language__Aua__, __language__Seimat__) and that of the Polynesian forms fails to agree, thus preventing a reconstruction.

[Mills (1975:813-814)](Source#cldf:mills1975) posited __language__Proto-South Sulawesi__ *_salaŋga_ ‘shoulder(?)’, with the voiced stop preserved in __language__Makassarese__, but changed in languages such as __language__Buginese__ through regular postnasal devoicing.  His gloss for both the __language__Buginese__ and __language__Makassarese__ forms is ‘breast bone of an animal’, but modern dictionaries give only ‘shoulder’ and verbs based on this noun.

Description: bovid, kind of wild bovid possibly Bos sundaicus

Comment: Also __language__Cebuano__ _taŋpi_ ‘bank of a body of water; edge of a surface; nearby, close by’.
The final syllable is shared, but nothing else.

Based on a somewhat larger version of this comparison [Ross (2008:317)](Source#cldf:rosspawleyandosmond2008) posited __language__POc__ *_(q)alipa_, *_lalipa_ ‘nut sp., possibly canarium almond’.  However, the comparison he presents shows no more regularity than the smaller one cited here, and his reconstruction cannot be justified by application of the Comparative Method.

Description: chattering: sound of a monkey chattering

Comment: [Mills (1981:68)](Source#cldf:mills1981) proposed ‘__language__Proto-Indonesian__’ *_kuta()_ ‘to chew’, but the sound correspondences in the penult are irregular, and the similarity of these forms may be a product of chance.

A perfect comparison, except that Philippine reflexes point unambiguously to a trisyllable, while those in northern Sarawak point just as unambiguously to a disyllable, leaving no clear basis for a reconstruction one way or the other.

Description: chiming: sound of tinkling or chiming
Comment: __language__Pangasinan__ points to *_karanciŋ_, but __language__Malay__ to *_karənciŋ_. This phonological discrepancy may be due to the onomatopoetic character of the word, but in any case a reconstruction is not currently possible.
Possibly a loan distribution.
If this comparison is valid the source of __language__Buli__ _-k_ is unclear, since *_k_ normally is lost in all positions.

The comparison of __language__Tiruray__ _seledoy_ with Greater Central Philippines forms such as __language__Hanunóo__ _sudláy_, or __language__Mansaka__ _sodlay_ suggests a __language__PPh__ *_suleday_, with metathesis of the medial cluster derived from schwa syncope in GCP.  However, although __language__Tiruray__ reduced prepenultimate _*a_ to schwa, it does not appear to have reduced high vowels in the same way, making a direct comparison with the GCP forms problematic.  __language__Maranao__, together with __language__Tiruray__ _seledoy_ could be taken as evidence for *_saleday_, but given their geographical contiguity, and evidence of heavy borrowing from Danaw languages into __language__Tiruray__ ([Blust 1992b](Source#cldf:blust1992)), this could easily be a loan distribution.
Borrowing from __language__Tagalog__.

Since at least [Milke (1938)](bib-Milke) there have been proposals for a __language__POc__ reconstruction *_lopu_ ‘cross-sibling’.  However, the evidence for such a form is very limited and contradictory.  
[Hambruch (1908)](Source#cldf:hambruch1908) reported __language__Wuvulu__ _lofu-na_ ‘cross-sibling’, but my own fieldnotes from 1975 show _olofu-_ ‘elder brother’ and __language__Aua__ _Lovu-_ ‘elder brother of a man’.  The other forms cited here fail to agree phonologically, and there is strong evidence that the __language__POc__ terms for ‘male’ and ‘female’ (*_maRuqane_, *_papine_) also functioned as cross-sibling terms, further weakening the argument for *_lopu_.

[Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) reconstructed *_iluk_ 'convex curve', but based his etymon solely upon reflexes in __language__Malay__ and __language__Javanese__ which appear to contain a common root, but which are not cognate.
The Polynesian evidence points to a __language__POc__ form with medial *_l_, while the __language__Motu__ evidence indicates *_r_.
__language__Tolai__ /_l_/ can only reflect *_l_, while __language__Mota__ /_r_/ must reflect *_r_ or *_R_.

[Mills (1981)](Source#cldf:mills1981) compared these and several other phonologically irregular forms, as __language__Yamdena__ _lifu_ ‘deep place in a river’ and propsed ‘__language__Proto-Indonesian__’ *_li(m)buŋ_ ‘deep or still water’.  However, none of the material he presents clearly supports a reconstruction at this stage.

Description: device: scarecrow device in paddy field

Comment: These words form a near comparison since __language__Isneg__ _lammó_ points to *_lemu_, and __language__Tagalog__ _hamóg_ possibly to *_lamuR_. In both cases there is a greater than chance resemblance with the established PAN reconstruction *_ñamuR_ ‘dew’.
The __language__Ibaloy__ form points to *_saŋgap_, while the other forms cited here all support *_saŋkap_.

__language__Agutaynen__ points to a form with initial *_q_ but final zero, while other languages support the reconstruction of final *_q_.  Since a reflex of __language__PAn__ *_asu_ ‘dog’ is preserved in some Philippine languages the meaning of this term presumably differed in some still undetermined way.

The western Indonesian forms are related, although some may be borrowed from __language__Malay__. The similarity of __language__Agta (Central Cagayan)__ _ləppu_, __language__Makatea__ _refu_ and __language__Proto-Polynesian__ *_refu_ to these is best attribued to convergence, although the similarity of form and meaning is striking.

Philippine and Bornean forms of this word are irreconcilable primarily because of discrepancies in the initial consonant, but also in some cases because of a lack of correspondence in the penultimate vowel.

This very tempting comparison is imperfect in two ways: 1. languages of the Admiralties point to *_u_ as the first vowel, while those in the Solomons indicate *_o_, 2. languages of the Solomons suggest a proto-form *_koburu_, while those in the Admiralties could only have reduced such a trisyllable to a disyllable if the last consonant was *_R_ (hence *_kobuRu_, with sporadic assimilation of the first vowel to the second, loss of *_R_ and contraction of the resulting sequence of like vowels).  Without data from other languages it is very difficult to tell whether this is a remarkable chance resemblance or a valid etymology with irregularities.

__language__Malay__ _surut_ can reflect *_suRut_ or *_surut_, while __language__Ilokano__ _úgot_ can reflect *_uRut_, thus providing no comparative basis for a reconstruction with or without an initial consonant.
__language__Lau__ /_l_/ reflects either *_l_ or *_R_, but __language__Motu__ loses *_l_ and reflects *_R_ as /_r_/.

Description: eels: trap for fish or eels
Comment: The __language__Ilokano__ form points to *_-b_, but the __language__Mansaka__ form to *_-p_.
Presumably from a __language__PPh__ *_elad_ or *_eled_, though reconstruction cannot be achieved with the evidence at hand.

The __language__Cebuano__ form cited here points to *_siluq_, and the __language__Malay__ and __language__Sasak__ forms to *_silu_. __language__Iban__ _siluʔ_ is compatible with neither of these, but together with __language__Cebuano__ _síluʔ_ could be taken as evidence for Zorc’s ([Zorc 1982](Source#cldf:zorc1982)) __language__PAn__ *_ʔ_, if it were not for the extremely problematic nature of that proposed proto-phoneme ([Blust 2013, sect. 8.2.2.4](Source#cldf:blust2013)).  Until further cognates are found, then, it seems best to treat this set as a near comparison.  Despite this limitation, this word is of some interest, as it is clearly a doublet of *_-ñilu_ and *_ŋilu_, both of which refer exclusively to the physical discomfort experienced in the teeth after eating something very sour or acid.  This meaning also is found in the __language__Iban__ and __language__Sasak__ forms cited here, but __language__Cebuano__, __language__Iban__ and __language__Malay__ all include an additional reference to emotional pain, and this seems to be the distinguishing feature of this variant.
__language__Maranao__ points to *_sambiq_, but __language__Iban__ to *_sambi_, with apparently secondary final glottal stop.
The variability in this form may be due to its highly expressive character, as it is usually uttered in moments of anguish or shock.
__language__Tboli__ _budas_ points to *_budas_ or *_bujas_, but __language__Kayan__ _bulah_ can only reflect *_bulas_. Also __language__Bikol__ _luʔdás_ ‘faded, discolored’.

__language__Saisiyat__ /_l_/ evidently points to *_N_ ([Li 1978:140](Source#cldf:li1978)), while the __language__Sangir__ and __language__Mongondow__ forms indicate *_l_.  All of these forms are assumed to contain the root [*-kas₃](root-acd-r_k.htm#-kas₃) ‘swiff, agile; energetic’ ([Blust 1988:105](Source#cldf:blust1988)).
__language__Uma__ _kediʔ_ reflects an undetermined final consonant *_-pb_, *_-td_, *_kg_, or *_q_, but __language__Paiwan__ has lost none of these consonants in final position.
__language__Kavalan__ points to a form with *_-p_, while __language__Paiwan__ supports only *_-b_.

Description: fly off: fly off, squirt out

Comment: __language__Yami__ and __language__Itbayaten__ point to a form with *_-t_, while __language__Ibaloy__ and __language__Pangasinan__ support *_-d_.

Given the close formal and semantic similarity of the __language__Tagalog__ and __language__Balinese__ members of this comparison it is tempting to propose a reconstruction, but the correspondence for the final consonant are irregular. Based on a similar comparison, [Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) reconstructed Uraustronesisch *_gagaq_ ‘to use force’, but he cited the __language__Tagalog__ form as having a final glottal stop that is not indicated in any Tagalog dictionary available to me.

Despite the distinctive semantic agreement of these terms and their general formal similarity it is impossible to achieve a reconstruction, since __language__Puyuma__ _ariH_ points to *_aliq_, __language__Paiwan__ _qali_ points to *_qali_, and __language__Tiruray__ _adih_ points to a proto-form with medial *_d_, *_j_ or *_z_.

At first glance these forms appear to share a monosyllabic root [*-lak ](root-acd-r_l.htm#-lak)‘shine’, but __language__Pazeh__ l reflects __language__PAn__ *_N_, while __language__PAn__ *_l_ > __language__Pazeh__ _r_.
This is a perfect comparison except for the last-syllable vowel, since __language__Paiwan__ points unambiguously to __language__PAn__ *_e_ and __language__Kavalan__ _u_ can only reflect *_u_.
The vowels of __language__Paiwan__ do not match those of languages in western Indonesia, although these forms undoubtedly are onomatopoetic, and may signal differences of voice pitch.

Description: hen: strut as rooster around hen

Comment: Perfect except that __language__Malay__ reflects *_-k_ or *_-g_, while __language__Tae'__ cannot reflect either.

__language__Pazeh__ _lezek_ can only reflect *_Nasek_, and __language__Bontok__ _lesek_ can only reflect *_lesek_ or *_Resek_. Both forms apparently contain the root [*-sek₂](root-acd-r_s1.htm#-sek₂) ‘insert, stick into a soft surface’.
The Philippine data support *_d_ as the second consonant, but __language__Puyuma__ indicates _*l_.

Also __language__Tagalog__ _kiwáɁ_ ‘left, left hand side’, __language__Ma'anyan__ _kawiɁ_ ‘left side’, __language__Malagasy__ _haví-a_ ‘the left side’, __language__Iban__ _kibaɁ_ ‘left’, _jari kibaɁ_ ‘left hand’, __language__Sundanese__ _kenca_ ‘left, left side’.  [Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) reconstructed *_kiwa_ ‘left, left side’, despite the far better supported __language__PAn__ *_wiRi_ in this meaning, and included __language__Malay__ _kiwa_ ‘be awkward, clumsy’ in his comparison, although no such form appears in [Wilkinson (1959)](Source#cldf:wilkinson1959).  This comparison is highly suggestive, but does not support a reconstruction.
With root [*-pik](root-acd-r_p.htm#-pik) ‘pat, light slap’.

Description: like wildfire or a disease: spread, like wildfire or a disease

Comment: In both languages *_s_ > _t_, so this might be derived from *_sikay_, but the glottal stop in __language__Agutaynen__ would still be unexplained, as this normally corresponds to __language__Paiwan__ _q_.

A perfect comparison except that the initial segments of these forms disagree, and __language__Kelabit__ _s_ in directly inherited forms is normally found only as the reflex of *_t_ before a high front vowel.

__language__Cebuano__ points to an etymon with *_b_, while languages of western Indonesia support *_p_.  The forms in at least __language__Old Javanese__, Modern __language__Javanese__ and __language__Sundanese__ probably are loans from __language__Malay__.

Description: mud puddle: mud puddle, pool of water

Comment: Philippine evidence points to *_amaŋ_, but Bornean evidence supports *_aməŋ_.
Perfect except that a medial _b_ : _m_ correspondence between these languages is otherwise unknown.
The __language__Pangasinan__ form points to *_silip_, but the __language__Mansaka__ form to *_silib_, and so far no arbiter that would allow us to favor one of these choices has been found.
These forms differ in reflecting the presence or absence of *_l-_, making reconstruction of a __language__Proto-Philippine__ form impossible.
__language__Amis__ _s_ reflects *_S_, but __language__Cebuano__ _s_ reflects *_s_.

Description: plant: black nightshade: plant: black nightshade, Solanum nigrum
plover sp.: sandpiper sp., plover sp.
Comment: [Clark (2011:361)](Source#cldf:clark2011) proposed __language__Proto-Remote Oceanic__ *_kVlili_ ‘Wandering tattler: _Heteroscelus incanus_’, but the evidence he presents does not permit a complete reconstruction.

Description: pool of water: puddle, pool of water

Comment: This comparison was proposed by [Osmond (2011:124)](Source#cldf:osmond2011), who reconstructed __language__POc__ *_toqa_ ‘kind of fish with toxic flesh, probably _Ostracion_’.

Description: queasy; urge to vomit: queasy, urge to vomit
queasy; urge to vomit: queasy, urge to vomit

Comment: With root [*-tuŋ](root-acd-r_t.htm#-tuŋ) ‘deep resounding sound’.
__language__Tagalog__ _pírit_ must reflect *_pidit_, while __language__Kelabit__ _pirit_ cannot.
The __language__Hanunóo__ word may be identical to _likúɁ_ ‘crook, bend (as in a stick, river, etc.)’.
Also __language__Malay__ _kərəmuntiŋ_ ‘evergreen shrub with an edible fruit, the rose-myrtle: _Rhodomyrtus tomentosa_’.

__language__Ibaloy__ _KabKab_ points to *_gabgab_. Both of these forms show the common association of initial velar stops in Austronesian languages with the notions ‘scratch, scrape, rub’ and the like.

Despite the generic similarity of these words the only forms that show sufficient agreement in sound correspondences to permit a reconstruction (*_maŋiwaŋ_) are __language__Sasak__ _maŋiwaŋ_, which appears to be a __language__Buginese__ loan, and the similar forms in __language__Buginese__ and __language__Makassarese__, which are very closely related.  These, together with __language__POc__ *_maŋewa_ strongly suggest a __language__PMP__ form similar to *_maŋiwaŋ_, but its precise form cannot be reconstructed based on currently available evidence.
__language__Maranao__ points unambiguously to *_a_ as the last-syllable vowel of this form, which Barito languages indicate either *_ə_ or *_u_.
Remarkably, although all of these forms are compatible with the first four segments of *_Siwi-_, none agree in identifying an ancestral final consonant.
The last-syllable vowels in these forms cannot be traced to a common source.
Probably a __language__Malay__ loanword in __language__Maranao__.
With incompatible medial consonants.
With root[ *-tak₂](root-acd-r_t.htm#-tak₂) ‘sound of cracking, splitting, cracking’ (?).

These items may share a common root with __language__Malay__ _bintaŋ_ 'star', but cannnot be considered cognate. [Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) segmented the initial consonants (_l-intaŋ_, _k-intana_) and posited a prototype *_intaŋ_, which is here rejected.
__language__Pazeh__ _lawat_ can only reflect *_Nawat_, and __language__Amis__ _lawat_ can only reflect *_lawat_ or *_Rawat_.

__language__Tagalog__ _ambáʔ_ may be a loan from some dialect of __language__Malay__ for which the form has not yet been reported (perhaps __language__Malay (Brunei)__)). However, the __language__Malagasy__ form cannot be explained in this way.
[Dempwolff (1938) posited](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) *_kuDug_ ‘roar, rumble’, but no reconstruction can be reached from the data given here.
The __language__CMP__ forms point to *_ləma_, and the Vanuatu forms to *_lama_.
Potentially from *_ŋaso_ or *_ŋeso_, but with disagreement of the penultimate vowel.  With initial velar nasal symbolizing the mouth and nose area ([Blust 2003a](Source#cldf:blust2003)).
__language__Tagalog__ _–g_ can reflect only _*g_ or _*R_, while __language__Malay__ _–y_ can reflect neither.

These forms certainly look like they should be related, but pretonic vowels normally became schwa in __language__Palauan__, and *_l_ became _y_.  The combination _əy_ before a stressed vowel would be expected to yield _i_, not _u_, hence **_kiát_.

Description: tree: Litsea sp.: tree: Litsea sp.
Comment: [Ross (2008:215)](Source#cldf:rosspawleyandosmond2008) used this comparison to propose __language__PCEMP__ *_lowaŋa_ ‘_Litsea_ sp.’. However, two of the three languages in his comparison show irregularities.  First, __language__Rembong__ (or the similar __language__Kepo__, which he also cites) cannot reflect a trisyllable with a final vowel, as all three syllables would regularly be retained.  Second, he gives __language__Lakalai__ _loaga_ ‘_Gmelia_ sp.’, but [Chowning](bib-Chowning) instead gives a form with final _-o_.  It is possible that __language__Lindrou__ (his source uses the alternative name ‘__language__Nyindrou__’) and __language__Lakalai__ reflect a __language__POc__ *_loaŋo_ and that the similarity of this form to __language__Rembong__ _loaŋ_ is a product of chance, but until better evidence is found it seems best to avoid proposing a reconstruction on any level.

Description: tree: Memecylon paniculatum: tree: Memecylon paniculatum
Comment: The __language__Batangan__ form may be _tamis-an_, and so point to *_tamis_, while the __language__Punan Tuvu'__ form points instead to *_temas_.
Fine, except that _g_ : _b_ is not a sound correspondence between these languages.
This set of forms, which [Dempwolff (1934-38)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) assigned to *_bali_ contains material reflecting two distinct etyma (*_balian_, *_baliw₂_).
[Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) proposed ‘Uraustronesisch’ *_teman_ ‘accustomed to’.

Description: address: term of address for females
address: term of address for girls
adze something: chop, split, adze something
Comment: The __language__Thao__ form could reflect either *_saqsaq_ or *_taqtaq_, the __language__Paiwan__ form only *_saqsaq_. Probably a chance resemblance.
Also  __language__Buli__ _bati_ ‘friend’.  Identical to [Dempwolff (1920)](Source#cldf:dempwolff1920) *_bati_ ‘house servants’, and probably a chance resemblance.

The suffixed *_-a_ in __language__Oceanic__ languages probably is identical to *_-a_ '3sg. object'. The prefixed _a-_ in __language__Malagasy__ and __language__Fijian__ is assumed to have no historical connection, either between these two languages, or with any of the suffixes cited here.

Description: ago: a moment ago, in a moment

Comment: The three Formosan forms almost certainly are cognate, and may point to __language__PAn__ *_Na_.  However, uncertainty concerning a possible Rukai-Tsouic subgroup, and the unknown history of borrowing between Rukai and Tsouic make such a reconstruction premature.  In any case, the similarity of the South Sulawesi words to these is probably best treated as a product of convergence.

Chance. The __language__Ngaju Dayak__  and __language__Malagasy__ terms reflect a __language__Proto-Barito__ innovation; those in __language__Bisayan__ languages reflect *_bitik_ 'spring up suddenly'.
Potentially a reflex of *_sabak_, but the limited distribution suggests that this is a product of chance.

Chance.  This is yet another example of the many forced comparisons in [Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438).  The __language__Ngaju Dayak__ form clearly reflects __language__PMP__ *_leŋen_ ‘forearm, lower arm’.  The loss of 
word-final _-n_ in obligatorily possessed nouns has led to reanalysis in other languages of Borneo, as in __language__Uma Juman Kayan__, where the reflex of __language__PMP__ *_ipen_ ‘tooth’ in constructions such as _ipen-naɁ_ ‘his/her tooth’ has be reinterpreted as _ipeɁ-naɁ_ ‘his/her tooth’ (with obligatory morpheme-final glottal stop).  The __language__Fijian__ word is most likely a reflex of __language__POc__ *_lima_ ‘hand’, with a sporadic replacement of *_m_ by its labiovelar equivalent, as with __language__Mota__ _limwa_ ‘hand; five’.  Dempwolff ignored the irregularity in the vowel correspondences of both syllables, and proposed Uraustronesisch *_liŋa_ ‘hand, arm’ despite the availability of far better-supported words for this meaning.

Chance. Together with the __language__Cebuano__ and __language__Aklanon__ forms, __language__Maranao__, __language__Manobo (Western Bukidnon)__ _irek_, __language__Mongondow__ _iok_ 'armpit' indicate __language__PCPh__ *_irek_.
Probably a reflex of *_qi_ 'genitive marker' in __language__Nggela__ and __language__Arosi__. I assume that the similarity to __language__Chamorro__ _i_ is due to chance.

[Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) used this comparison to propose *_puhun_ ‘to ask permission’.  However, I am unable to find the __language__Tagalog__ form in any dictionary available to me, or in any other Philippine language, and the __language__Malagasy__ word, if cognate, may be a __language__Malay__ loan.

[Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) proposed *_si(dD)aŋ_ ‘steep, precipitous’, but this comparison appears to be confined to __language__Ngaju Dayak__ and __language__Malagasy__. It is thus best treated as ‘noise’ not on grounds of false cognation, but rather on the grounds that it cannot be reconstructed for a proto-language of any considerable time-depth.
[Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) proposed ‘Uraustronesisch’ *_daga_ ‘to be related’, but [Dahl (1976:106-107)](Source#cldf:dahl1976) has rightly dismissed this comparison as invalid.

__language__Aklanon__, __language__Hiligaynon__, __language__Palawan Batak__, __language__Cebuano__, __language__Maranao__ and __language__Sundanese__, __language__Old Javanese__, __language__Javanese__, __language__Balinese__ form two distinct low-level cognate sets. The similarity of these sets to one another and to __language__Nias__ _furi_ is attributed to chance.

[Dempwolff (1934-38)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) reconstructed *_p-al-upuq_ 'vegetable matter', which he regarded as a doublet of *_p-al-aqpaq_/. Apart from __language__Malay__ and __language__Javanese__, however, there is little evidence for such an etymon. The similarity of the __language__Tagalog__ and __language__Iban__ forms to __language__Malay__ _pelupoh_, __language__Javanese__ _plupuh_ is best attributed to chance.

Chance. There is a great temptation to compare __language__Bontok__ and __language__Ifugaw__ with __language__Tanjong__ and __language__KAJA__ under an etymon *_balat_, but __language__Ilokano__ _bárat_ suggests that this would be an error. Also cp. __language__Sebop__, __language__Bintulu__, __language__Melanau (Mukah)__, __language__Lara Land Dayak__ _balak_/ 'banana'.
Chance, or borrowing from __language__Malay__.

This is an example of the extreme lengths [Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) sometimes went to in order to force a comparison semantically when the sound correspondences permitted the reconstruction of a phonemic form.  He glossed the __language__Javanese__ form ‘maize without kernels’, but that is not the gloss in [Horne (1974)](Source#cldf:horne1974), and I am unable to find the form at all in [Pigeaud (1938)](Source#cldf:pigeaud1938).  Similarly, __language__Futunan__ _kalu-mata_ does not appear in [Moyse-Faurie (1993)](Source#cldf:moysefaurie1993), and even if it did the semantic distance between this and __language__Tagalog__ _kalót_ is so great as to render any comparison too speculative to take seriously.
Resemblance of __language__Hanunóo__, __language__Cebuano__ to the others due to chance. The other items probably spread by borrowing.

[Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) posited *_kanTuŋ_ ‘Korb, Tasche am Kleid’ (basket, pouch on the clothing).  However, as he noted, the last vowel of the Oceanic forms fails to agree with that of his reconstruction.  The forms in western Indonesia appear to be loans from __language__Malay__ which the __language__Fijian__, __language__Tongan__ and __language__Samoan__ forms resemble by chance.
Apparently a chance resemblance. Although __language__Old Javanese__ _usuh_ may contain the root *_-seq_ 'wet; wash', *_e_ is regularly reflected as //o// in all of the __language__Batak__ languages.

Description: be out of breath: pant, be out of breath
Comment: Tempting as it is to accept this as a valid comparison, the sound correspondences simply do not work.  The __language__Puyuma__ vowels disagree with those of the __language__Paiwan__ and __language__Ibaloy__ forms, and although the latter two languages appear to show a perfect agreement, __language__Paiwan__ /_s_/ reflects *_S_ and __language__Ibaloy__ /_s_/ reflects *_s_, making reconstruction impossible.  Like many other bases with initial velar nasal, this one probably is a product of convergent innovation involving the phonestheme _ŋ-_, widely associated in Austronesian languages with the nasal-oral area ([Blust 2003a](Source#cldf:blust2003)).
This is an example of the type of comparison that clutters [Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) and distracts attention from the many valid etymologies he recognized.

[Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) used this comparison with __language__Javanese__ _kəwut_ ‘beat out’ instead of the __language__Sundanese__ form cited here.  However, I am unable to find a __language__Javanese__ form meeting this description in either [Horne (1974)](Source#cldf:horne1974) or [Pigeaud (1938)](Source#cldf:pigeaud1938), and the __language__Tagalog__ form is both phonologically irregular and semantically deviant, leaving little comparative basis for a reconstruction.
Probably chance, although both forms appear to contain the root *[-kel](root-acd-r_k.htm#-kel) 'bend, curl'.

Description: between: space between earth and sky

Comment: __language__Malay__ probably borrowed from __language__Javanese__, possibly through the medium of a __language__Tagalog__ dialect (though [Panganiban](bib-Panganiban) does not list a cognate form for Standard __language__Tagalog__). The resemblance of __language__Tetun__ to __language__Malay__, __language__Javanese__ and __language__Sasak__ is attributed to chance.

Description: blood: stench of fish or blood
Comment: The __language__Ngaju Dayak__, __language__Malay__ and __language__Javanese__ forms are cognate, but probably represent a late innovation in western Indonesia. The resemblance of the __language__Tagalog__ and __language__Malagasy__ forms to these is assumed to be a product of chance, and although the South Sulawesi forms appear to be cognate, they point to an etymon with penultimate *_e_, and so do not permit a clear-cut reconstruction.

Despite the rather striking general resemblance of these forns this comparison is phonologically irregular, as is best treated as a  product of chance.  [Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) posited ‘Uraustronesisch’ *_tulup_ ‘blowpipe’, but __language__PMP__ *_sumpit_ is a far better candidate for this meaning.
Based on this comparison [Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) proposed Uraustronesisch *_calcal_ ‘to hack off’.

[Dempwolff](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) reconstructed *_bani(r)_, and [Tsuchida (1976)](Source#cldf:tsuchida1976) posits *_baNiR_/.  I regard __language__Saaroa__, __language__Tsou__, __language__Paiwan__ and __language__Ngaju Dayak__, __language__Malay__, __language__Acehnese__, __language__Sundanese__, __language__Sasak__ as forming two geographically restricted cognate sets. The resemblance of these sets to one another and to __language__Selaru__ and __language__Yapese__ is attributed to chance.

[Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) posited *_ketug_ ‘to beat, pound’ based on a comparison of this __language__Tagalog__ form with __language__Javanese__ _ketug_ ‘to beat out’.  I am unable to find the latter form in either [Horne (1974)](Source#cldf:horne1974) or [Pigeaud (1938)](Source#cldf:pigeaud1938), and have substituted __language__Old Javanese__ _kətug_ for it.
In either case, until further supporting evidence is found this comparison is best treated as a product of chance.

[Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) posited *_te(m)biŋ_ ‘edge, bank’, but this is one of the rare comparisons in which he allowed massive irregularity, since the expected  __language__Fijian__ reflex would be **_tovi_ or **_tobi_, and the __language__Ngaju Dayak__ form also shows an unexplained irregularity in the first vowel.  The remaining forms are best regarded as late innovations in western Indonesia, or as loans from __language__Malay__.

Despite its initial appeal this comparison is problematic in at least two ways.  First, Philippine languages disagree among one another with regard to the presence or absence of a final glottal stop, suggesting a history of borrowing.  Second, given the unexplained discrepancy in number of syllables between Philippine and Oceanic forms the wider comparsion is best treated as a chance resemblance.

I am unable to find __language__Tagalog__ _dalaŋ_ in this meaning in either [Panganiban (1966)](Source#cldf:panganiban1966) or [English (1986)](Source#cldf:english1986), and the __language__Samoan__ form, which appears to refer to the shininess produced by a greasy surface, appears only in [Pratt (1984)](Source#cldf:pratt1984).  [Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) proposed ‘Uraustronesisch’ *_daDaŋ_ ‘to shine, be bright’, but without better evidence this comparison is best considered a product of chance.

[Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) proposed *_segseg_ ‘to burn’, but the __language__Malagasy__ form is phonologically irregular, and the semantic connection of the __language__Tagalog__ and __language__Toba Batak__ forms is too general to permit a secure inference of cognation.

[Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) posited ‘Uraustronesisch’ *_tela_ ‘burst open’ (_aufbersten_).  I am unable to find the __language__Tagalog__ form that he gives in any modern dictionary, and the wider comparison is best attributed to chance.

This probably is best treated as a collected of unrelated forms until such time as better comparative data is available.  [Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) reconstructed Uraustronessisch *_liŋaw_ ‘still, calm’ (_Stillsein_).

[Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) used this comparison to posit ‘Uraustronesisch’ *_taduq_ (dbl. *_te(n)duq)_ ‘calm, of the wind’ (_Windstille_).  However, I am unable to find the __language__Tagalog__ form in any modern dictionary of the language, and even if it were available, it is phonologically irregular, lacking a final glottal stop.  In addition, __language__Ngaju Dayak__ _tadoh_ is ambiguous for a form with penultimate *_a_ or _*e_, and the __language__Sa'a__ form is best treated as a chance resemblance.

Description: certain: ten, in counting certain objects

Comment: Chance. [Dempwolff (1934-38)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) combined these forms with __language__Ngaju Dayak__ _iwa-n_ 'sister-in-law (woman speaking)'.
Probably best treated as a convergent development with the common monosyllabic root [*-pak₁](root-acd-r_p.htm#-pak₁) ‘slap, clap’.
Based on this comparison [Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) proposed *_te(m)bak_ ‘to clear forest’.

[Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) proposed *_pezam_ ‘close the eyes’ (dbl. (*_penDem_), but the __language__Toba Batak__ form is better treated as a __language__Malay__ loan, and the __language__Fijian__ and Polynesian forms, which show multiple phonological irregularities, as chance resemblances to the forms in insular Southeast Asia.

__language__Malay__ _baloŋ_ may be cognate with the first two syllables of the northern Philippine forms. Until more information is available, however, this comparison is perhaps best treated as a product of chance.

Given the availability of much stronger comparisons for this meaning, and the absence of known comparable forms in any non-Polynesian language apart from __language__Wandamen__, this comparison is best treated as a product of chance.

The __language__Philippine__ forms are unrelated to those in western Indonesia. Of the latter only __language__Bidayuh (Bukar-Sadong)__ and __language__Malay__, or __language__Malay__ and the __language__Batak__ languages permit a comparison, and this cannot safely be attributed to __language__PWMP__.

Description: come across by chance: meet, come across by chance
Comment: These two have probably met by chance, as no other supporting evidence for this comparison is known.

The similarity of __language__Makassarese__ _ballasaʔ_ to the other forms cited here probably is due to chance. The remainder of this comparison is best regarded as a late innovation in western Indonesia, with likely borrowing either from __language__Malay__ or from __language__Javanese__.

Chance. Despite the non-conforming __language__Ngaju Dayak__ form and the wide latitude in semantics [Dempwolff 1934-38](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) proposed this comparison presumably on the assumption that the affixed form in __language__Javanese__ was a clearer indication of the meaning of the base form than the base form itself.
Most of the items both in western and eastern Indonesia are assumed to be loans from __language__Malay__. The similarity of __language__Pohnpeian__ _piŋ_ to these forms is attributed to chance.

[Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) reconstructed *_kaliŋ_ with the vague gloss ‘Zwischenstück’ (‘connecting piece’), using it to combine a collection of semantically disparate forms solely on the grounds that they could all be assigned to a reconstruction of the same shape.
[Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) proposed ‘Uraustronesisch’ *_tuŋkəq_ ‘piece, connecting piece’.
[Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) proposed *_kekel_ ‘constant, steady’, but the evidence he presented provides little convincing support for his reconstruction.

This is an example of a type of comparison that is unfortunately rather common in [Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438), namely one in which the semantics of forms that would allow a higher-level reconstruction are extremely forced and artificial (the __language__Ngaju Dayak__ and __language__Javanese__ forms, which are semantically compatible, cannot safely support a reconstruction, given the longstanding __language__Javanese__ influence on __language__Banjarese__ and __language__Ngaju Dayak__).  Unlike most of the chance resemblances for which Dempwolff proposed __language__PAn__ reconstructions this one also shows an unacknowledged phonological irregularity, since he cites __language__Fijian__ _i-tabi_ ‘flat basket’, while [Capell (1968)](Source#cldf:capell1968) instead gives _tabe_ ‘to hold or carry with the hands under’, _i-tabe_ ‘a small oval basket without handles’.

[Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) reconstructed ‘Uraustronesisch’ *_taki_ ‘contradict someone’ (_widerede_), based on __language__Tagalog__ _taki-taki_ ‘digression’ and the __language__Malay__ word given here, but I am unable to find his __language__Tagalog__ form in [Panganiban (1966)](Source#cldf:panganiban1966) or [English (1986)](Source#cldf:english1986), and the available evidence does not strongly support a reconstruction with the shape and meaning he proposed.
The __language__Tiruray__ form is assumed to be a __language__Manobo__ loan; the similar of the __language__Rotinese__ and __language__Motu__ forms to these is attributed to chance.

Chance. __language__Toba Batak__ _oŋkol_ probably contains a root *_-kel_, seen in such __language__Philippine__ forms as __language__Manobo (Sarangani)__ _kelkel_ and __language__Kalamian Tagbanwa__ _kulkul_ 'cough'.

[Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) proposed *_kukak_ ‘cough’, but the support given for this is too weak to merit a reconstruction without further evidence (__language__Malagasy__ should reflect *_k-_ as _h_, and __language__Toba Batak__ should reflect *_u_ as _u_).
[Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) reconstructed ‘Uraustronesisch’ *_taman_ ‘yard, courtyard’ (_Hof_), but there is little likelihood that any of these forms are related.
The Bornean forms point to *_ateb_; the similarity of __language__Tagalog__ _atáb_/ and __language__Muna__ _ghonto_ to these is attributed to chance.
[Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) proposed __language__PAn__ *_tambeŋ_ ‘covered, veiled’ for what is best treated as a collection of unrelated forms.

This is one of the most remarkably speculative of all Dempwolff etymologies.  The forms in western Indonesia refer exclusively to spears or lances, and those in Polynesian languages to land crabs, but here he has tried to force a connection by assuming that the primary reference in the latter case is to the claw of the crab, imagined as somehow believed to be lance-like (rather than pincer-like, which is far more likely).  [Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) reconstructed ‘Uraustronesisch’ *_tumbak_ ‘crab claw, lance’ (_Krebsschere, Lanze_).

Although initially tempting, this comparison is problematic in two respects: 1. the final correspondence appears to be without parallel, 2. the referent in __language__Philippine__ languages evidently is the bony structure of the body in general rather than the skull in particular. With regard to the first of these points [Zorc (1982:115)](Source#cldf:zorc1982) has argued for the reconstruction of __language__PAn__ *_-q_, *_-ʔ_, and *_-h_. __language__Amis__ _foŋoh_ points to an etymon with *_-h_, but this is cohtradicted by all __language__Philippine__ witnesses, which can indicate only *_-q_ or *_-ʔ_.

Based on these four forms and Javanese laḍaŋ ‘clearing’, [Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) reconstructed Uraustronesisch *_laḍaŋ_ ‘cropland’.  However the __language__Javanese__ form cannot be located (the closest I have found is [Pigeaud](Source#cldf:pigeaud1938)’s _laḍaŋ_ ‘good opportunity; room to do something’).  Apart from the __language__Iban__ and __language__Malay__ forms, which are clearly cognate, but show __language__Iban__’s recurrent pattern of antonymy [(Blust 1981)](bib-(Blust), the remaining forms are best treated as a collection of random similarities.
[Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) reconstructed ‘Uraustronesisch *_teba_ ‘cultivated land’ (_Fruchtland_), but without better evidence this reconstruction appears fanciful.
[Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) posited *_keDut_ ‘curl’, but there is little semantic cohesion to this set of formally compatible words.
Chance (cp. __language__POc__ _*paRi_ 'cut or lop off branches').
Based on the forms given here [Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) reconstructed *_zu(ŋ)kit_ ‘cut off’, a form that now appears to be unsupportable.
Chance.  [Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) reconstructed ‘Uraustronesisch’ _*Ta(r)ik_ ‘round dance’ (_Reigen_), but nothing of the kind appears to be justified.
Chance. __language__Manggarai__ _babek_ may be a loan from a southern Sulawesi source.

Chance. [Kähler (1961)](Source#cldf:kahler1961) cites this comparison, but __language__Mongondow__ _y_ can only reflect *_d_, *_r_, or *_y_, none of which are regular sources of __language__Simalur__, __language__Nias__ _-l-_.

Also __language__Toba Batak__ _hunsi_ ‘closed, locked’, a borrowing of __language__Malay__ _kunci_ ‘lock or bolt’, metathesized in _hinsu_. [Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) posited *_ki(n)cu_ ‘deceit, fraud’.

[Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) posited ‘Uraustronesisch’ *_tubiR_ ‘deep place in the water’ (_Wassertiefe_), but the meaning in Central Philippine languages is consistently ‘water’ or ‘juice’, and no forms have been found that might be used to bridge the gap to the semantics of the __language__Malay__ term.

[Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438)  posited Uraustronesisch *_laba(r)_ ‘pleasant flavor’ (_Wohlgeschmack_).  However, if the __language__Toba Batak__, South Sulawesi and __language__Malay__ forms are related it is probably through borrowing, and the similarity to __language__Sa'a__ _laha_ is best attributed to chance.
[Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) reconstructed ‘Uraustronesisch’ *_teges_ ‘to mark, designate’ (_bezeichnen_).

Chance. [Dempwolff (1934-38)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) compared the above terms and __language__Tongan__, __language__Futunan__, __language__Samoan__ _mala_ 'misfortune, bad luck, scourge, plague'. He recognized that the __language__Polynesian__ forms cannot regularly reflect *_walat_, but failed to recognize that __language__Javanese__ _walat_ is also irregular, since *_wa-_ became __language__Javanese__ _o-_ (*_wada_ > _ora_  'not', __language__Old Javanese__ _wwalu_ > Mod. __language__Javanese__ _wolu_/ 'eight'). __language__Javanese__ _Nalat_ has no known etymology (__language__Madurese__ _balat_ 'misfortune' presumably is a loan), but must derive from earlier *_balat_.

[Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) posited *_sukar_ ‘dirt, filth’ on the basis of these two forms, but the sound correspondences are irregular, and there is no known support from other languages.

[Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) proposed Uraustronesisch *_laŋes_ ‘dirt, filth’ (_Schmutz_).  The __language__Isneg__ and __language__Ifugaw__ words form a ‘near comparison’ with Central Philippine forms such as __language__Cebuano__ _laŋsá_ ‘having a fishy smell or the taste of blood’.

[Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) proposed this comparison, which appears to be a collection of unrelated forms in all three languages.  I am unable to find _sona_ in [Richardson (1885)](Source#cldf:richardson1885), and the closest form I can find to his _so-sol_ is _sol_ ‘uprooted (by storm)’ in [Pigeaud (1938)](Source#cldf:pigeaud1938).

Also __language__Fijian__ _dewa_ ‘to spread abroad, e.g. of a disease that becomes epidemic’.  [Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) posited ‘Uraustronesisch’ *_tiwas_ ‘disastrous, incurable’, but despite some marginal plausibility this comparison seems best attributed to chance.
__language__Malay__ _bodok_ is assumed to be a loan from __language__Javanese__. The similarity of the __language__Philippine__ forms to those in western Indonesia is attributed to chance.

[Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) reconstructed *_seba(r)_ ‘disseminate, strew around’, but plausible cognates are found only in western Indonesia, where they may be borrowings from __language__Malay__. __language__Fijian__ _cova_ does not appear in [Capell (1968)](Source#cldf:capell1968).

Proposed in [Blust (1970)](Source#cldf:blust1970) as *_(CtT)eŋbur_ ‘dive’, but this now seems misguided, as the initial consonant of __language__Rotuman__ _jopu_ reflects the nasal grade of *_s-_, and __language__Fijian__ _tobu-raka_ reflects __language__PAn__ *_Cebuj_ ‘natural spring, fresh water spring’.

Also: __language__Malay__ _pintu gerbaŋ_ 'lynch-gate', __language__Rejang__ _baŋ_/ 'door'. Chance, with possible convergence based on a common root *_-baŋ_ 'open out'. __language__Lau__, __language__Kwaio__ _baba_ may reflect *_papan_ 'plank, board'.
Chance (cp. __language__Kayan__ _ba_ 'mouth', evidently the primary sense of the term).

Chance.  I cannot find a __language__Tagalog__ word of this shape with the stated meaning in any modern dictionary.  Based on these two forms, and __language__Javanese__ _luh_ ‘tears’, which clearly reflects __language__PAn__ *_luSeq_, Dempwolff (1938) nonetheless proposed Uraustronesisch *_luRuq_ ‘to drizzle’.

Based on a comparison of the above __language__Tagalog__, __language__Malay__, and __language__Javanese__ words, together with __language__Toba Batak__ _tabu_ ‘alarm drum’, [Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) reconstructed __language__PAn__ *_tabuq_ ‘drumstick’.  He then extended this inference to *_tabuqan_ ‘yellowjacket wasp’ by suggesting that the latter is *_tabuq-an_, and is semantically linked with *_tabuq_ through the drumming sound that the yellowjacket wasp reportedly makes.  However, I find nothing like the __language__Toba Batak__ word he cites in [Warneck (1906)](Source#cldf:warneck1977), or in dictionaries of any other Batak language, and the __language__Tagalog__ word is semantically very distant from the forms in western Indonesia.  In short, I consider this whole enterprise fanciful, since there is no sound evidence for *_tabuq_ ‘drumstick’, and without this as a beginning the analysis of *_tabuqan_ --- which is highly questionable on morphological and semantic grounds in any case --- is vacuous.
Probably a chance resemblance.  [Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) proposed __language__PAn__ *_tibag_ ‘dug out, excavated’.
Probably convergent innovation from a common root *[-beŋ₃](root-acd-r_b.htm#-beŋ₃) 'dull resounding sound'.
__language__Bugotu__ and __language__Arosi__ point to __language__PSES__ *_papa_; the resemblance of __language__Rarotongan__ _aa_ to these forms is attributed to chance.
Potentially a reflex of *_zalit_, but given their limited distribution the similarity of the Philippine forms to __language__Nggela__ is best attributed to chance.

Description: elder sibling: father, uncle, elder sibling

Comment: Without any other known form that can be compared with these, and given the irregular vowel correspondence in the penultimate syllable, this comparison is best treated as a product of chance.  [Dempwolff (1934-1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) posited ‘Uraustronesisch’ *_mesaq_ ‘enemy’.
The resemblance of __language__Kankanaey__ _imók_ to the __language__Central Philippine__ forms is attributed to chance.
__language__Gedaged__ _baz_, __language__Gitua__ _baram_ 'k.o. tree: _Erythrina indica_' probably are cognate. The similarity of these to the other forms cited here is attributed to chance.
Probably an independent development, motivated by a still poorly understood set of language universals (those governing non-auditory sensory iconicity).

[Dempwolff](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) cited __language__Tagalog__ _lasáɁ_ ‘destroyed, demolished’, and posited Uraustronesisch *_lesaq_ ‘drained, exhausted’,  but I find nothing of the kind in any modern dictionary of __language__Tagalog__, and even if it existed the penultimate vowel would be irregular.
[Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) reconstructed *_sindak_ ‘experience fear’, but the comparison fails to carry conviction.
The resemblance of the __language__Tolai__ form to those in Central Pacific languages probably is a product of convergence.

There is no compelling reason to consider this anything more than a collection of unrelated forms.  [Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) proposed *_kusem_ ‘faded’, noting the phonological irregularity of the __language__Javanese__ form.

On the basis of the comparison [Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) posited ‘Uraustronesisch’ *_leŋeR_ ‘lame’.  The Old and Modern Javanese forms appear to be __language__Malay__ loanwords, and the __language__Tagalog__ form (which I am unable to find in my sources) probably is best treated as a product of chance.

Based on this comparison [Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) proposed ‘Uraustronesisch’ *_lancuŋ_ ‘to falsify, forge, counterfeit’.  However, the meaning of the __language__Ngaju Dayak__ form departs radically from this sense (based on a statement in [Hardeland (1859)](Source#cldf:hardeland1859) that the rich wear gold instead of brass armbands he speculated that the latter were considered ‘counterfeit’).  The __language__Toba Batak__ form shows an unexplained _-m_, and the __language__Fijian__ form also departs widely in meaning.

[Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) compared the forms given here with __language__Malagasy__ _pelika_ ‘to fan, vibrate, using them to posit Uraustronesisch *_pelik_ ‘to vibrate’.  I am unable to find a form that matches his __language__Malagasy__ citation in any dictionary available to me, and even if it could be found, the semantic latitude allowed in this comparison and the phonological irregularity of the __language__Malagasy__ form weigh heavily against accepting this as a valid etymology.

Based on the __language__Tagalog__ and __language__Javanese__ forms given here [Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) proposed ‘Uraustronesisch’ *_tuluy_ ‘fast’ (_schnellsein_).  It is difficult to see what might have motivated this decision.
__language__Tiruray__ _ufaw_ is assumed to be a __language__GCPh__ loan; the relationship of __language__Malagasy__ _ofo_ to the __language__Philippine__ forms is attributed to chance.

[Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) proposed *_sisip_ ‘to feign, pretend’ based on data from __language__Tagalog__, __language__Toba Batak__, __language__Javanese__ and __language__Samoan__. I am unable to find an equivalent of his __language__Tagalog__ form in either [Panganiban (1966)](Source#cldf:panganiban1966) or [English (1986)](Source#cldf:english1986), or an equivalent of his __language__Samoan__ expression in either [Pratt (1893)](Source#cldf:pratt1984) or [Milner (1966)](Source#cldf:milner1966).  However, even if these words were taken at face value this comparison would remain unconvincing without further support.
[Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) reconstructed ‘Uraustronesisch’ *_tegeŋ_ ‘steadfast, firm’ (_standhaftsein_).

Chance. One of the most contrived and unconvincing comparisons in [Dempwolff (1934-38)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438), this proposed cognate set (which includes __language__Lampung__ _iwa_ 'fish', __language__Sundanese__ _iwak_ 'fish') should simply be discarded.

The resemblance of __language__Cebuano__ _baluʔ_ to the other forms is probably a product of chance. Some of the __language__Oceanic__ forms (particularly the __language__Polynesian__ forms) may be related, but a specific common gloss is yet to be found.
The similarity of __language__RALU__ _ive_ to the __language__Polynesian__ forms is attributed to chance.

Chance. __language__Gilbertese__ _itu_ may be cognate with __language__Motu__ _Jituri_ 'a string of fish' (< __language__POc__ *_i-tuRi_ 'instrument for stringing'), but this interpretation cannot be applied to __language__Nggela__ _itu-itu_.
A Dempwolff comparison of very limited distribution and questionable validity

[Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) proposed __language__PAn__ *_tambaŋ_ ‘side, opposite side, cross side’, glossing the __language__Malay__ and __language__Javanese__ forms as ‘überqueren’ (‘cross over’), and the __language__Fijian__ form as ‘side’, but this meaning does not occur in [Capell (1968)](Source#cldf:capell1968).  The entire comparison is extremely forced, and best treated as a collection of random similarities.

[Ranby (1980)](Source#cldf:ranby1980) gives __language__NANU__ _iti_ as a borrowing from English, but __language__Gilbertese__ _iti_ would appear to be a more likely source. The resemblance of these forms to __language__Proto-Ambon__ *_iti_ is regarded as a product of chance.
Chance. Other comparisons such as *_buŋbuŋ(-an)_ 'ridge pole show clearly that the house in __language__WMP__ society had a sloping roof.
The forms in western Indonesia probably represent a __language__Malay__ loan distribution, while __language__Rennellese__ _papa_ is assumed to be a chance resemblance.

On the basis of the above forms, all of which he glossed as ‘flattened bamboo’, [Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) reconstructed __language__PAn__ *_tepas_ ‘pressed flat’.   However, I have been able to find this gloss only in the __language__Toba Batak__ form, and the __language__Javanese__ and __language__Toba Batak__ forms are phonologically irreconcilable.
Despite the striking resemblance of this form among related languages the lack of support in any language outside Bunun and Polynesian strongly suggests that this comparison is a product of chance.

[Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) posited *_kebut_ ‘fold together, wrap’, but the resemblance of the __language__Tagalog__ form to the __language__Fijian__ and Polynesian words seems is best attributed to chance.
The __language__Isneg__ and __language__Sasak__ forms may be independently affixed forms of *_pæn_. The similarity of __language__Mentawai__ _iba_ to these is attributed to chance.

[Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) added __language__Fijian__ _lolo-a_ ‘unwell; seasickness’ to this and posited Uraustronesisch *_leles_ ‘lose consciousness’ (_das Bewustsein verlieren_).  This is best treated as a chance resemblance.
The forms in __language__Javanese__, __language__Sundanese__ and __language__Balinese__ are cognate, but the similarity of these to __language__Tagalog__ _apulaʔ_ is due to chance.

Dempwolff cited these forms in support of Uraustronesisch *lawlaw ‘weak, feeble’ (_Schwachsein_).  However, I find no __language__Tagalog__ form with the meaning given, or anything close to it in any modern dictionary of the language, and the whole comparison is best treated as a product of chance.

Based on a slightly different version of this comparison [Mills (1981)](Source#cldf:mills1981) proposed __language__PAn__ *_la(m)baR_ ‘free; rebellious’.  However, almost nothing about this comparison works: the __language__Tagalog__ word is semantically at odds with the others cited here, __language__Acehnese__ _labaih_ can only reflect *_labas_, the __language__Madurese__ form contains a penultimate vowel that disagrees with the reconstruction, and the other forms are confined to languages in central or southwest Sulawesi, where borrowing cannot safely be ruled out with regard to __language__Buginese__ or __language__Makassarese__ influence on __language__Bare'e__.
All-in-all this form is best regarded as a loanword.  I am indebted to Alexander Smith for bringing this to my attention.

Based on this comparison [Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) posited Uraustronesisch *_puhaŋ_ ‘empty’ (_leersein_), citing the gloss of __language__Fijian__ _vua_ as ‘uninhabited’ (_unbewohnt sein_).

Based on this comparison (minus __language__Old Javanese__) [Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) proposed ‘Uraustronesisch’ *_Deŋu_ ‘cessation of breathing’ (_Atem Stockung_).  Given the semantic looseness of his comparison it seems best to attribute it to chance, pending further evidence.

Also __language__Kavalan__ _btuq_ ‘explode’.  __language__Malay__ _bertéh_ probably derives from _ber-_ + _retéh_, as in _meretéh_ ‘springing up in little jerks, like shrimps jumping about in a landing basket’.
Chance. [Adriani (1928)](Source#cldf:adriani1928) refers the __language__Bare'e__ forms to __language__Indonesian__ _wali_ 'ghost', but cites no supporting evidence.

Based on the above data (except for __language__Old Javanese__) [Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) reconstructed *_suRsuR_ ‘to slide, glide’.  However, I have not found his __language__Tagalog__ form in either [Panganiban (1966)](Source#cldf:panganiban1966) or [English (1986)](Source#cldf:english1986), and even if it is accepted, there is too little semantic agreement among any of the forms cited here to permit a confident reconstruction.

[Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) proposed *_sibsib_ ‘glide off, slide off’, but his comparison is both semantically and phonologically unconvincing.  Neither the __language__Old Javanese__ form (substituted for Dempwolff’s __language__Javanese__ _sisib_, which I cannot find in [Pigeaud 1938](Source#cldf:pigeaud1938) or [Horne 1974](Source#cldf:horne1974)) nor __language__Fijian__ _sisi_ has any obvious semantic connection with the Polynesian words or with one another, at least under the meaning ‘glide off, slide off’.  Moreover, the latter reflect __language__POc__ *_sipo_, and are thus morphologically _hi-hifo_, _si-sifo_, not _hihif-o_, _sisif-o_.
[Dempwolff (1934-1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) posited ‘Uraustronesisch’ *_dampul_ ‘adhesive, glue’ (_Klebstoff_).

Chance. [Dempwolff (1934-38)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) compared __language__Toba Batak__ _barut_ with __language__Tagalog__ _bagót_ 'exasperated; in a state of ennui or impatience', __language__Malay__ _barut_ 'bandaging; long wrapper or bandage', and proposed *_baRut_ 'goiter'. Neither of the latter words, however, appear to be cognate with the __language__Batak__ forms (__language__Tagalog__ _bagót_ almost certainly contains a root *_-gut_ 'angry').

Chance. [Tsuchida (1976:141)](Source#cldf:tsuchida1976) assumes cognation of the __language__Formosan__ forms and __language__Ilokano__ _biél_, with assimilation of the last vowel in __language__Bunun__ and the __language__Tsouic__ languages, but this hypothesis requires at least two independent instances of sporadic assimilation in the same lexical item (one in __language__Proto-Tsouic__, the other in __language__Bunun__). Given this problem and the occurrence of still other phonetically similar but non-corresponding forms (as __language__Puyuma__ _buʔur_) I prefer to treat this comparison as a product of chance.
__language__Malay__ non-cognate, __language__Ngaju Dayak__ possibly an early borrowing from __language__Javanese__.

Chance. [LeBar](bib-LeBar)'s __language__Sasak__ _balo_/ and __language__Bimanese__ _waro_ are phonologically compatible, but [Goris (1938)](Source#cldf:goris1938) gives __language__Sasak__ _baloʔ_ 'great grandfather', _be-baloʔ_ 'crocodile', and __language__KOM__ _waro_ suggests that the medial consonant in __language__Bimanese__ _waro_ does not derive from *_l_.
[Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) reconstructed ‘Uraustronesisch’ *_taŋtaŋ_ ‘to grip, grasp’ (_mit her Hand greifen_).
[Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) posited *_kuRkuR_ ‘to rub, grate’.  I am unable to find __language__Tagalog__ _kugkog_ in any modern dictionary.
Chance, although all three contain a likely root *_-ŋer_ 'growl' seen also in __language__Maranao__ _ŋeŋer_ 'growl, howl, grunt'.
