Based on the comparison of these forms plus __language__Ngaju Dayak__ _laba_ ‘have a result’, and __language__Javanese__ _labah_ ‘addition, supplement’ (_Zusatz_), [Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) posited Uraustronesisch *_labaq_ ‘increase, growth’.   However, [Hardeland (1859)](Source#cldf:hardeland1859) gives __language__Ngaju Dayak__ _laba_ ‘exceptionally lucky’ (_vorzugsweise glücklich_), and I am unable to find a similar __language__Javanese__ form in either [Horne (1974)](Source#cldf:horne1974) or [Pigeaud (1938)](Source#cldf:pigeaud1938).  Given the collapse of the rest of his comparison and the absence of newer support  the relationship between the __language__Tagalog__ and __language__Toba Batak__ forms given here is best attributed to chance.
Chance or borrowing.

Description: hand: scrape or scratch with the hand
Comment: Chance.  [Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) posited ‘Uraustronesisch’ *_Ta(ŋ)kur_ ‘scrape or scratch with the hand’ (_mit der Hand scharren_).  In addition to the above forms he included __language__Tagalog__ _taŋkol_ ‘hand movement’ (_Handbewegung_), but no such word appears in either [Panganiban (1966)](Source#cldf:panganiban1966) or [English (1986)](Source#cldf:english1986), and I am unable to find corresponding forms in other Philippine languages.

__Based on a slight variant of this comparison [Dempwolff (1934-1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) reconstructed ‘Uraustronesisch’ *_makas_ ‘hard’, but *_maka_ appears to be a Tongic innovation that replaced __language__Proto-Polynesian__ *_fatu_ ‘stone’, and so has little time-depth even within Polynesian.
Chance. For __language__Motu__ _papa-ia_ cf. note to *_bajbaj_.

Although both of these bases could reflect __language__POc__ *_fula_, the absence of supporting evidence from other languages, and the occurrence of the base only with another word or with affixation raises suspicions that this rather striking resemblance is a product of chance.
[Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) reconstructed *_siraŋ_ ‘to form gaps’, but this comparison appears to be a forced collection of unrelated forms.

[Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) compared the __language__Tagalog__, __language__Malagasy__ and __language__Toba Batak__ forms given here, and proposed ‘Uraustronesisch’ *_panduŋ_ ‘head covering; crest’.  The similarity between these forms now seems better treated as due to chance, and while the Philippine forms are clearly cognate and share the monosyllabic root [*-duŋ](root-acd-r_d.htm#-duŋ) ‘shelter, protect’, the Cordilleran words appear to be __language__Tagalog__ loans.

The __language__Fijian__ and __language__Polynesian__ forms may be cognate, though borrowing cannot be ruled out ([Churchward 1959](Source#cldf:churchward1959) does not list __language__Tongan__ _ʔafuha_, and the anticipated form in any case would contain first-syllable //_o_//, not //_a_//). The relationship of the __language__Malagasy__ and __language__Sa'a__  forms to these and to one another is regarded as convergent (cf. __language__Lau__ _ʔafuta_ 'all, every', __language__Arosi__ _ʔahuta-na_ 'all, the whole of, all together', and similar forms in other __language__Southeast Solomonic__  languages which indicate earlier *_kafusa_).
Borrowing from __language__Malay__, except for __language__Dairi-Pakpak Batak__ _burut-en_, which is best attributed to chance.

[Osmond, Pawley and Ross (2003:95)](Source#cldf:osmond2003) cite an equivalent, but slightly longer comparsion in support of __language__POc__ *_loka_ ‘high sea or tide, heavy breakers’.  However, the __language__POc__ status of the reconstruction they propose depends crucially on the __language__Lou__ example, and since __language__Lou__ regularly loses all final vowels that were not protected by an obligatory suffix the similarity of __language__Lou__ _loka_ to the other forms cited by them is best attributed to chance.

On the basis of this rather unpromising comparison [Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) posited ‘Uraustronesisch’ *_cawad_ ‘to hinder’.  I have been unable to find cawad in any Javanese dictionary available to me, or in Old Javanese.
Probably a chance resemblance.
Chance (based on a common root *_-bek_ 'sound of breaking, etc.').

Chance. Despite the striking formal and semantic similarity of these forms the correspondences are irregular (__language__Kadazan Dusun__ _o_ points to *_e_, __language__Tiruray__ _u_ to *_u_). The __language__Tiruray__ form shows irregularities associated with __language__Danaw__ loans, but a cognate word is yet to be identified in a __language__Danaw__ language (or, for that matter, any other language).
The __language__Malagasy__ form appears to be a chance resemblance, and the __language__Toba Batak__ form could easily be a loan from __language__Malay__.

Late innovation, with some borrowing for __language__Malay__, __language__Toba Batak__, __language__Dairi-Pakpak Batak__, __language__Sundanese__, __language__Old Javanese__; chance for __language__Gilbertese__.

This comparison, first proposed without the __language__Bikol__ member in [Blust (1970)](Source#cldf:blust1970), has long been problematic because the Philippine evidence points to *_-q_, but the __language__Iban__ evidence is incompatible with this [(Blust 2009:561-568)](bib-(Blust).  There is a very strong temptation to assume cognation here, but on balance the similarity of these forms is perhaps best attributed to chance.

Dempwolff compared the __language__Tagalog__ form with __language__Malagasy__ _vaza_ ‘disdain, contempt’ and proposed *_baya(q)_ ‘neglect’, but this is best considered a chance resemblance, and the form reconstructed only for __language__Proto-Philippines__.

For reasons that remain unclear [Dempwolff (1934-38)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) compared these disparate forms, which he assumed to be connected through the common meaning ‘interior’ (given by him as ‘interior of the land = Northwest’, ‘interior of the house = dwelling’).  Entirely apart from the error in the directionality of the __language__Tagalog__ term this is an uncharacteristically uncontrolled piece of etymological speculation for a scholar who was generally much more cautious.

[Richards (1981:28)](Source#cldf:richards1981) compares the __language__Iban__ form with __language__Malay__ _keris bahari_ ‘kris with a long, narrow, straight blade’.  Other terms that may be related are __language__Thao__ _balis_ ‘iron (metal)’, and __language__Kavalan__ _baris_ ‘nail’.  However, the __language__Thao__ word is clearly a loan, probably from __language__Bunun__ (although our lexicographic resources for the latter are insufficient to determine this with certainty), and the semantically deviant __language__Kavalan__ form evidently reflects a prototype with medial *_l_ rather than *_r_ or *_R_ ([Li and Tsuchida 2006:8](Source#cldf:liandtsuchida2006)).  By way of counterbalancing these problems, there is a second comparison (__language__Palawan Batak__ _karát_ ‘rusty’, __language__Malay__ _karat_ ‘rust’) which provides independent support for an early knowledge of iron.  On balance, this is perhaps best regarded as a chance resemblance, but the number of suggestive forms and the potential value of a comparison with this meaning keeps hope alive.  The term *_bari_ is discussed at some length in [Blust (1976)](Source#cldf:blust1976) and [Blust (1999)](Source#cldf:blust1999), where it is suggested that it may have referred to meteoric iron.

The __language__Label__, __language__RALU__ and perhaps __language__Tanga__ words are related through direct inheritance from a common proto-form, and the __language__Asilulu__ and __language__Buruese__ words are related through borrowing. The similarity between these two sets and between either of them and __language__Fordata__ _vuar_ appears to be due to chance.

Based on this comparison plus __language__Javanese__ _ḍakəp_ ‘laid next to one another’ [Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) proposed ‘Uraustronesisch’ *_Dakep_ ‘to join together’.  I am unable to find the Javanese form in any source available to me, and the semantic agreement of the other forms is suggestive, but not sufficiently convincing in my view to justify a reconstruction at this time.
The __language__Saisiyat__ form must reflect *_maNat_, while the __language__Kayan__ form can only reflect *_malat_.
The similarity of __language__Old Javanese__ _hidep_ and __language__Javanese__ _idep_ to the __language__Polynesian__ forms is attributed to chance.
Chance. Although this item might be considered a doublet of *_palacipaq_, __language__Tae'__ _balaʔbaʔ_ appears to derive from an infixed form of *_bejbej_ (cf. __language__Tae'__ _baʔbaʔ_).
Best treated as a chance resemblance.  [Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) reconstructed Uraustronesisch *lindiq ‘lie above’ (_obenliegen_).

Based on this comparison [Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) posited Uraustronesisch *piŋgaŋ ‘loins’.  The __language__Javanese__ word probably is a __language__Malay__ loan, and the __language__Malagasy__ word, which Dempwolff glossed  ‘move the legs’ (_Bein stellen_) is best ignored.

Based on the first four members of this comparison [Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) proposed Uraustronesisch *lawas ‘long duration’ (_lange Dauer_).  However, there is little semantic coherence in this comparison, and it is best treated as a product of chance until better evidence can be found to support it.
A product of chance.  [Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) posited ‘Uraustronesisch’ *_luga(r)_ ‘sparse, not dense’ (undicht).
The resemblance of __language__Ilokano__ _úga_ and of __language__Rarotongan__ _uŋō_/ to the other forms and to one another is attributed to chance.

Apparently reconstructible for __language__PCEP__. The __language__Paiwan__ and __language__Amis__ forms disagree in pointing to *_Si_ and *_i_ respectively. I take the resemblance of __language__PCEP__ *_i_ to all other forms cited here as a product of chance.
Borrowing from __language__Malay__. [Wilkinson (1959)](Source#cldf:wilkinson1959) suggests that this may ultimately be a loan from Persian.
The similarity of __language__Bidayuh (Bukar-Sadong)__ _ambok_ to the northern __language__Philippine__ forms is due to chance.

Based on this comparison [Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) proposed   ‘Uraustronesisch’ *_labur_ ‘to melt’.  I am unable to find the __language__Tagalog__ form in any source available to me, and the similarity of these forms seems in any case better attributed to borrowing from __language__Malay__, chance or both.

[Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) proposed *_sebut_ ‘mention, refer to’, but the __language__Fijian__ form is phonologically irregular, and the __language__Ngaju Dayak__ and __language__Javanese__ forms could be loans from __language__Malay__.
[Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) reconstructed ‘Uraustronesisch’ *_teleŋ_ ‘middle’ (_Mitte_).

Description: moor a boat: stop by, to moor a boat
Comment: Based on this comparison [Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) proposed ‘Urindonesisch’ *_tuli_ ‘to moor; stop by to visit’ (Einkehren, Anlegen).

Since this form has been found nowhere else I treat it as a product of chance convergence pending the discovery of more support.  [Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) proposed Uraustronesisch *_piTut_ ‘to narrow, contract’ (_verengen_).

Chance. Although __language__LAKA__ _bolo-_ and __language__Kwaio__ _ono_ could reflect __language__POc__ *_ciono-_, the __language__Kwaio__ form appears to reflect *_tonom_ 'to swallow' (cf. _onom-anal_ 'throat, necḱ, _onom-ia_ 'swallow').
On the basis of this compariosn Dempwolff (1938) proposed ‘Uraustronesisch’ _cepat_ ‘quick, nimble’.
Chance. [Adriani (1928)](Source#cldf:adriani1928) identifies __language__Bare'e__ _ba_ as an ellipsis of _iba_.
Probably a chance resemblance.  [Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) positied Uraustronesisch *_lali_ ‘unnoticed, not perceived’ (_Unbemerktsein_).

[Mills (1981)](Source#cldf:mills1981), citing [Benedict (1975:286)](Source#cldf:benedict1975) as his source, uses this comparison, together 
with an unrevealed __language__Makassarese__ form that cannot be located in any published source, in part because no actual form is given, to posit __language__PAn__ *_lawlaw_ ‘oil’.  However, both Formosan forms reflect *_NawNaw_, which normally yields __language__PMP__ *_n_, not *_l_, and these themselves may be a product of borrowing, since this characterized the relationship of __language__Paiwan__ and __language__Puyuma__ for centuries ([Blust 1999:47-51](Source#cldf:blust1999)).  Needless to say, since the resemblance of __language__Fijian__ _lolo_ to the words from southern Taiwan is both formally flawed and semantically deviant, it is best treated as a product of chance.

It is conceivable that this is one of a set of numerals used for special purposes, as by children in play.  However, there is no known support for this hypothesis beyond the present comparison, and until  further support is found it seems best to treat the similarity seen here as a product of chance convergence.

[Dempwolff (1934-38)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) reconstructed *_wawaq_ 'opening', but the __language__Javanese__ form is best attributed to *_babaq₂_ and the __language__Malagasy__ form to *_babaq₁_. The similarity of __language__Tagalog__ _wáwaʔ_ to __language__Sa'a__ _wawa_ is best attributed to chance.

[Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) reconstructed ‘Uraustronesisch’ *_tataR_ ‘rule’, adding __language__Fijian__ _i-tata_ ‘order, command’, a form that I am unable to find in any modern dictionary.

[Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) posited *_kedut_ ‘pain’, but the __language__Tagalog__ form is irregular (expected **_kurót_), and is a not a convincing semantic match for __language__Javanese__ _kedut_.

The resemblance of __language__Balinese__ _ental_ to the other forms cited here is attributed to chance. The __language__Lau__ and __language__Arosi__ forms must reflect earlier *_osa_, and __language__Rotuman__ _ota_ must be a loan, although its source remains problematic. This leaves __language__Mota__ _ota_, __language__Anuta__ _ota_ 'sago palm' as the only clearly cognate forms, but given the evidence for borrowing in __language__Rotuman__ this distribution is perhaps best regarded as a product of diffusion.
The __language__Tagalog__ linker and the __language__Hanunóo__ conjunctive particle are assumed to be cognate. The resemblance of the other forms to these is attributed to chance.
Most likely a chance resemblance.  [Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) reconstructed Uraustronesisch *_lepa_ ‘paste’.
Reconstructible as __language__PCP__ *_isi_. The resemblance of __language__Rotinese__ _isi_ to __language__PCP__ *_isi_ is attributed to chance.
Chance, although both forms appear to contain the root *[-bak₃](root-acd-r_b.htm#-bak₃) 'split off, separate'.

Chance. For an alternative etymological connection for __language__Cebuano__ _paflut_ cf. __language__POc__ *_paro_. For an alternative view of the __language__Cebuano__:__language__Malay__ comparison which is now rejected cf. [Blust (1970)](Source#cldf:blust1970).

[Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) posited *_serep_ ‘penetrate’, a form that was accepted in [Blust (1972)](Source#cldf:blust1972), but for which the supporting evidence is now considered unconvincing.

Based on the __language__Tagalog__ and __language__Malagasy__ forms [Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) proposed ‘Uraustronesisch’ *_tulut_ ‘permission’, despite a lack of comparative support for his proposed gloss.

[Mills (1981:75)](Source#cldf:mills1981), who cites both the __language__Buginese__ and __language__Makassarese__ words with a simplex _k_, proposed __language__PAn__ *_si(ŋ)kit_ ‘to pick up’, but the known evidence does not appear strong enough to rule out chance convergence.

[Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) included these forms under ‘Uraustronesisch’ *_zuluk_ ‘pierce, penetrate’ (_Stechen_).  However, there is little to recommend this comparison, which appears to be a collection of formally compatible words that have almost nothing else in common.  It is true that the meaning ‘penetrate, bore through’ in __language__Toba Batak__ _man-julluk_ is fairly similar to ‘put in, insert, sheathe’ in __language__Samoan__ _sulu_, but the medial geminate is unexplained (Dempwolff wrote _ju<l>luk_), and it is further noteworthy that __language__Tongan__ _hulu_ ‘to fix one’s loincloth by tucking in one end of it at the waist; to tidy up the edges of a mat by tucking in the protruding ends’, was omitted despite its obvious cognation, presumably because it would weaken the argument for comparing the __language__Samoan__ form with those in insular Southeast Asia

[Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) proposed *_(s)eRa(q)_ ‘place of burning’, but this comparison is both formally and semantically problematic, and is best treated as a product of chance convergence.

Despite the clear phonological irregularity in the initial consonant, and the divergent semantics of the __language__Malay__ and Polynesian forms [Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) posited __language__PAn__ *_tempet_ ‘place of residence’.
Chance, or if related, __language__Aklanon__, __language__Cebuano__, __language__Maranao__, __language__Mongondow__ reflect an innovation in __language__PCPh__.

Chance. __language__Cebuano__ _pálaw_ 'large vigorously growing aroid: _Cyrtosperma/ merkushii_', __language__Maranao__ _palao_ 'cultivated taro: _Xanthosoma violaceum Schott._ suggest a __language__PCPh__ *_pálaw_ 'large aroid: _Cyrtosperma_ spp.'. The __language__Tagalog__ word shows secondary suffixation.
The __language__Old Javanese__ and __language__Balinese__ words are cognate. The similarity of the __language__Isneg__ and __language__Kayan__ forms to these and to each other is due to chance.

[Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) cited __language__Fijian__ _i-so-somi_ ‘seedling’, but this is not the sense of this term in __language__Bauan Fijian__ as given by [Capell (1968)](Source#cldf:capell1968), or in __language__Wayan__ as given by [Pawley and Sayaba (2003)](Source#cldf:pawleyandsayaba2003).  In the absence of further evidence this comparison is best treated as a  product of chance.

This comparison proposed by [Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) appears to bring together completely unrelated forms.  I am unable to find __language__Tagalog__ _sahot_ in either [Panganiban (1966)](Source#cldf:panganiban1966) or [English (1986)](Source#cldf:english1986), and __language__Samoan__ _sau_ does not occur in this meaning in any dictionary I have been able to consult, including [Pratt (1893)](Source#cldf:pratt1984), which was Dempwolff’s source.
Chance?

[Dempwolff](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) proposed *_zuru_ ‘point, tip’ (dbl. *_duRu_ ‘corner’), and included such semantically divergent forms as __language__Malay__ _juru_ ‘trained worker (at some occupation other than a handicraft)’ and __language__Javanese__ _juru_ ‘person who performs a certain [skilled] job’, under the general gloss ‘master’ (also cf. __language__Old Javanese__ _juru_ ‘head, leader, chief (of a division, military or administrative; of a group or trade); tradesman, trained worker’).  The entire collection seems extremely forced, and is best abandoned as ill-conceived.
[Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) reconstructed ‘Uraustronesisch *_taki_ ‘point out directions’.

The __language__Ngaju Dayak__, __language__Malay__ and __language__Javanese__ forms are related, but probably a product of borrowing from __language__Malay__ (with __language__Ngaju Dayak__ _tihaŋ_ from __language__Banjarese__).  The similarity of the Oceanic forms to these is best treated as a product of chance.  [Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) reconstructed ‘Uraustronesisch’ *_tiaŋ_ ‘pole, rod’ (_Pfahl, Stange_) and dismissed the __language__Ngaju Dayak__ form as irregular, but __language__Old Javanese__ confirms the medial consonant (< *_q_).
[Dempwolff (1934-1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) proposed ‘Uraustronesisch’ *dahup ‘weak’.

The __language__Malay__ and __language__Javanese__ words given here are clearly Arabic loans.  The __language__Tagalog__ word looks like it could be a borrowing from __language__Malay__, but if so it would be the only known case in which a __language__Malay__ _r_ has been borrowed as a __language__Tagalog__ _g_, mimicking the correspondence reflecting __language__PAn__ *_R_.  For now it seems best to consider the resemblance of the __language__Tagalog__ word to those in __language__Malay__ and __language__Javanese__ a product of chance.

Despite a problem with the medial consonant correspondence, the __language__Bikol__, __language__Aklanon__, and __language__Hiligaynon__ affixes appear to be cognate. The similarity of these forms to __language__Kayan__ _pala-_, __language__RALU__ _wara-_ is attributed to chance.

Based on forms in __language__Toba Batak__ and __language__Javanese__ [Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) posited *_sikep_ ‘ready, prepared’.  However, the __language__Karo Batak__ form shows that __language__Proto-Batak__ had *_siŋkeb_, which is phonologically incompatible with the forms in __language__Old Javanese__, __language__Javanese__, __language__Balinese__ and __language__Sasak__, leaving either a comparison with relatively little time-depth, or a loan distribution.

None of these forms appear to be related, yet [Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) combined them under Uraustronesisch *le(m)bu ‘preserved, protected, hedged in’ (_Eingehegt_), in a proposed 
etymology that is best dismissed as a product of chance.

The __language__Hanunóo__ and __language__Gorontalo__ forms presumably are related. Although both exhibit regular phonological correspondences with the similar words in __language__Ngadha__ and __language__Rotinese__ , this is not the case with __language__Manggarai__ _Nuʔa_ (where a final _l_ is expected). Since the __language__Manggarai__, __language__Ngadha__ and __language__Rotinese__ forms almost certainly are cognate with one another (but not with __language__Asilulu__ _huʔak_) this leaves two low-level cognate sets (one __language__GCPh__, the other __language__Lesser Sundas__) and a potpourri of chance resemblances.

This comparison was the subject of a tortuous discussion in the earlier literature based on: 1. an approach to linguistic reconstruction which circumvented the normal scientific procedure of triangulation in the justification of inferences, and 2. a failure to distinguish directly inherited from borrowed forms ([Dyen 1953:363ff](Source#cldf:dyen1953), [Hendon 1964:377ff](Source#cldf:hendon1964)). The __language__Ngaju Dayak__, __language__Iban__ and __language__Malay__ words clearly reflect __language__PAn__ *_buRaw_ 'drive off, chase away, expel' with the atypical, but recurrent change *_-aw_ > _u_. All other forms in island Southeast Asia appear to be __language__Malay__ loans, as attested by lexical doubletting in __language__Karo Batak__, __language__Toba Batak__ and __language__Dairi-Pakpak Batak__, where a directly inherited reflex of *_buRaw_ is found next to the __language__Malay__ loanword, with semantic differences that are consistent with a borrowing hypothesis. Given the relatively complete integration of this loanword into the affixational systems of some of these languages (e.g. __language__Toba Batak__, and the appearance of _buru_ in __language__Old Javanese__ texts it appears likely that this word was borrowed fairly early in most languages (perhaps during the classic Sriwijaya period, circa 7th century AD). The similarity of the __language__Southeast Solomonic__  forms to those in western Indonesia is attributed to chance.
Probably a chance resemblance.  [Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) posited ‘Uraustronesisch’ *_tunzaŋ_ ‘push, shove’ (_stossen_).

[Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) proposed *_sulaŋ_ ‘to reach across’ based on this comparison plus __language__Javanese__ _sulaŋ_ ‘impart, communicate’.  However, I am unable to find the latter entry in either [Pigeaud (1938)](Source#cldf:pigeaud1938) or [Horne (1974)](Source#cldf:horne1974), and the remaining forms are insufficient to propose a reconstruction with confidence.
__language__Kenyah__ and __language__Puluwat__ are due to chance. Most others appear to reflect *_baRah_ 'ember' or *_baReq_ 'abscess, inflammation'.
The __language__Toba Batak__ word is borrowed from __language__Malay__; the similarity of the __language__Javanese__ form is due to chance.

This comparison was proposed by [Geraghty (1990:73)](Source#cldf:geraghty1990), who reconstructed *_taReRe_ ‘rejoice’, based on data from only four specific languages: __language__Palauan__ _merrós_ ‘to crow (rooster)’, __language__Tolai__ _rore_ ‘to rejoice, be happy, as when joining in a dance’, __language__Nggela__ _ulele_ ‘triumphant, rejoicing’, and the __language__Sa'a__ form given here.  However, of these only __language__Sa'a__ _alele_ regularly reflects *_taReRe_, and the claim that Central Pacific languages reflect Proto-Central Pacific *_taē_ has not been confirmed through independent checking of published sources on __language__Rotuman__, __language__Fijian__ or any Polynesian language.
[Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) used this comparison to propose *_kucup_ ‘relationship between the sexes’, but it contains nothing to distinguish it from a chance resemblance.

[Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) posited *_sapin_ ‘replenishment, restoration’ on the basis of these two terms, but there is no obvious connection between them, and the __language__Tagalog__ form is better assigned to __language__PPh__ *_sapin_ ‘lining, insulation, padding’.

Chance. [Dempwolff (1934-38)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) cited __language__Toba Batak__ _adi_ with the German gloss _Ruhm_ ('glory, renown, fame'), but his source ([Warneck 1906](Source#cldf:warneck1977)) actually gives _adi_ 'ruhen' ('to rest').
Apparently a chance resemblance.  [Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) posited ‘Uraustronesisch’ *_lu[s]aw_ ‘to rinse off’ (_ausspülen_).
[Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) reconstructed ‘Uraustronesisch’ *_tanzak_ ‘kind of ship’s sail’ (_Name eines Seiles an Schiffen_), but no convincing comparison in fact exists.
The __language__Old Javanese__ and __language__Balinese__ forms appear to be borrowed from __language__Sanskrit__. The resemblance of the remaining items is attributed to chance.

On the basis of this comparison [Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) posited Uraustronesisch *_pulu(rR)_ ‘roll into a ball’ (_zusammenballen_).  However, the divergent semantics of the __language__Ngaju Dayak__ and __language__Toba Batak__ forms makes it hard to justify a plausible etymology, and the resemblance of the __language__Malay__ and __language__Javanese__ forms is best considered to be a product of borrowing from __language__Malay__.

This is one of many comparisons in Dempwolff (1938) that appear convincing at first sight, but which unravel on closer inspection.  His gloss of ‘Zusammenballen’ [_make into a ball_] seems to be chosen solely from Toba Batak, and completely lacks any kind of comparative support.
Based on this comparison [Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) posited ‘Uraustronesich’ *_tarap_ ‘row’.

Chance. [Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) compared these forms to __language__Tagalog__ _ulós_ 'wound caused by a pointed instrument; act of striking with a speaŕ and __language__Javanese__ _urus_ 'affair, matter; to handle, take care of; administer a laxative' under a proposed etymon *_ujus_.

The similarity of __language__Pangasinan__, __language__Kapampangan__, __language__Tagalog__ is attributed to borrowing from __language__Tagalog__. The similarity of these forms to __language__Puyuma__, __language__Paiwan__ and to __language__Itbayaten__ is regarded as a product of chance.
[Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) proposed _*sa(rR)əp_ ‘refuse, garbage’.  However, further supporting evidence has not been found, and the status of this form remains in doubt.
[Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) reconstructed _*se(m)buq_ ‘satiated’, but no reconstruction of any great time-depth appears possible from this comparison.

The resemblance of __language__Buli__ _iwa_ to the forms in __language__CMP__ languages probably is due to chance. The __language__CMP__ forms may be related, but it is not clear that a form found only in __language__Moa__, __language__Wetan__ and __language__Kei__ must derive from a __language__PCMP__ etymon.
On the basis of this comparison [Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) posited ‘Uraustronesisch’ *_ca(ŋ)kap_ ‘to scoop up’.
The resemblance of the __language__Mongondow__ form to the similar words in eastern Indonesia is attributed to chance.
[Dempwolff](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) posited *_kaDus_ ‘stroke, scratch’ based on these two forms, which appear to have no connection with one another.

This rather fanciful etymology was used by [Dempwoff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) to reconstruct *_kunTul_ ‘scrotum’.  However, the __language__Javanese__ form is probably a __language__Malay__ loan, and the __language__Sa'a__ form a chance resemblance arising from the general meaning ‘round object, lump’ (aside from which *_kuntul_ would regularly yield *_Ɂuu_, not *_ɁuɁu_).  A far better-supported term for this meaning in __language__PMP__ *_laseR_ ‘scrotum and testicles’.

[Wolff (2010:812)](Source#cldf:wolff2010) proposes __language__PAn__ *_dabedab_ ‘set fire to’ on the  basis of these three words.  However, the __language__Kelai__ form is not reported in [Blust (1993)](Source#cldf:blust1993), or [Amster (1995)](Source#cldf:amster1995), nor does a similar word appear in the __language__Lun Dayeh__ dictionary of [Ganang, Crain, and Pearson-Rounds (2006)](bib-Ganang).  Wolff’s ‘__language__Kelai__ _dadab_’ is thus a ghost form that serves no legitimate purpose in this etymology, and the semantic divergence of the __language__Amis__ and __language__Tagalog__ items does not instill confidence that the comparison is valid.
Chance?

Following a suggestion first made by [Adriani (1928:411)](Source#cldf:adriani1928), [Mills (1981)](Source#cldf:mills1981) proposed a slightly different version of this comparison, and posited ‘__language__Proto-Indonesian__’ *_luŋkut_ ‘ashamed’.  However, the phonological correspondences are irregular, and the __language__Tagalog__ form is semantically distinct from the words in languages of Sulawesi.
This comparison appears to be a product of chance.  Despite several problems with the data [Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) reconstructed *_kiu_ ‘shark’.

[Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) assigned the above words along with __language__Javanese__ _karah_ ‘metal piece by which a blade is affixed to a handle’, __language__Toba Batak__ _hara_ ‘turtle’ and __language__Sa'a__ _kara_ ‘to scrape, to grate’ to *_karaq_ ‘shell’.  However, the __language__Javanese__ and __language__Sa’a__ forms are semantically distant from the others, the __language__Toba Batak__ form does not appear in [Warneck (1977)](Source#cldf:warneck1977), and of the remaining forms __language__Tagalog__ _kála_ and __language__Malay__ _karah_ are phonologically incompatible. This leaves just the __language__Tagalog__ and __language__Malagasy__ forms as potential comparata, and the similarity between them hardly seems to depart from chance.

[Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) assigned the above words along with __language__Javanese__ _karah_ ‘metal piece by which a blade is affixed to a handle’, __language__Toba Batak__ _hara_ ‘turtle’ and __language__Sa'a__ _kara_ ‘to scrape, to grate’ to *_karaq_ ‘shell’.  However, the __language__Javanese__ and __language__Sa'a__ forms are semantically distant from the others, the __language__Toba Batak__ form does not appear in [Warneck (1977)](Source#cldf:warneck1977), and of the remaining forms __language__Tagalog__ _kála_ and __language__Malay__ _karah_ are phonologically incompatible. This leaves just the __language__Tagalog__ and __language__Malagasy__ forms as potential comparata, and the similarity between them hardly seems to depart from chance.

[Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) cited __language__Tagalog__ _tábal_ as ‘name of a shrub’, but I cannot find it in any modern dictionary of the language, or in [Madulid (2001)](Source#cldf:madulid2001), and this comparison is consequently best considered a chance resemblance.

[Dempwolff (1934-1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) proposed this comparison (less the __language__Iban__ form), assuming that the __language__Fijian__ form shows an otherwise unpreceded syllable metathesis.  However, I can find _luma_ in no __language__Fijian__ dictionary at my disposal, and the form that Dempwolff apparently mean is _druma_ ‘foolish, clumsy, stupid’, a word that has no obvious relationship to those in western Indonesia (most of which may be __language__Malay__ loans).

Chance. [Dempwolff (1934-38)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) compared these forms, but was forced to recognize a fossilized affix in the __language__Malagasy__ word (_h-ira_), __language__Tagalog__ and __language__Bikol__ _híla_ appear to be connected with _híla_ 'pull, drag, tow, haul; a load, as a unit measure for haulage'.
Probably a chance resemblance.

Chance.  [Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) proposed Uraustronesisch *_linsad_ ‘to slip, slide’ (Ausgleiten), but I cannot find either the __language__Malay__ or __language__Javanese__ forms in any modern dictionary, 
and the residual comparison is feeble.

On the basis of this comparison [Dempwolff](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) reconstructed ‘Uraustronesisch’ *lurus 
‘slip off’.  However, the __language__Javanese__ form appears to contain the adversative passive circumfix 
_ka- -en_, found in a number of other forms, making the base _milurus_ rather than _lurus_. [Pigeaud (1938)](Source#cldf:pigeaud1938) gives __language__KAMI__ ‘to pine away’ (_wegkwijnen_), with no morpheme division, while Dempwolff, citing the earlier work of [Jansz (1913)](Source#cldf:jansz1913) gives the somewhat different sense ‘have a panic attack’ (_von Schreck befallen sein_).  In any case this proposed cognate set shows little semantic coherence, and is best treateed as a product of chance.

Despite its excellent semantic match and near-perfect formal match, this comparison is only possible by accepting a unique correspondence of _d-_ in __language__Tagalog__ and other Philippine languages, to _l-_ in __language__Malay__.  This comparison was tentatively accepted in [Blust (1970)](Source#cldf:blust1970), where it was noted, however (152), that “__language__Ml__. _l_ < *_d_ in this form has no known parallels.  While chance cannot be completely ruled out as an explanation of the formal and semantic resemblance of these items, the probability seems high that the comparison is valid.  An explanation for the discrepant initial segment of the __language__Malay__ word has not yet been found.”  Today, 43 years later, we still lack an explanation.

Convergent innovation. Most of the forms cited here show multiple iconicity, beginning with a low vowel which approximates the position of the mouth at the onset of a sneeze, proceeding through an alveolar or palatal fricative or affricate, which mimics the oral closure preceding the release of a sneeze, and ending with a high vowel (plus nasal), which mimics the narrowed oral aperture and partial nasal channel which typically terminates a sneeze.
Probably products of chance convergence motivated by universal sound symbolism.

Probably a convergent semantic innovation from __language__PMP__ *_paRa_ 'storage shelf', since the latter was located above the hearth. In this connection cp. __language__Malay__ _araŋ para_ ('soot' + 'storage shelf') 'soot'.

__language__Tae'__ _iʔduk_ and __language__Manggarai__ _iruk_/ may contain a variant of the root *_-dek_ 'hiccough, sob'. Whether this turns out to be the case or not, the similarity of these forms is best attributed to convergence.

Based on this comparison [Ross (2003:110, 239)](Source#cldf:osmondpawleyandross2003) proposed __language__POc__ *_loto_ ‘space within a concave object’.  However, the expected __language__Loniu__ reflex of a __language__POc__ *_loto_ would be **_lot_, not _lɔtiye_, and Polynesian reflexes suggest that there are two distinct cognate sets, one reflexting *_loto_ ‘inner self, feelings, mind’, and the other ‘pool, possible inside the reef’.  The former is reconstructed based on evidence from Vanuatu and Polynesia, but any attempt to propose a reconstruction for the latter earlier than __language__Proto-Central Pacific__ (or perhaps more realistically, __language__Proto-Polynesian__) is currently premature.

Dempwolff used the __language__Toba Batak__, __language__Ngaju Dayak__ and __language__Malagasy__ forms to reconstruct *_siak_ ‘spicy tasting’.  However, the __language__Toba Batak__ form does not appear to be cognate with those in the Barito languages, leaving us with unrelated reconstructions in __language__Proto-Batak__ and __language__Proto-Barito__.  Despite this shortcoming a gloss was assigned based on the meaning in a single witness.
The Oceanic members of this comparison may be related, but until better evidence is available the resemblance between all of these forms is treated as a product of convergence.

[Mills (1981)](Source#cldf:mills1981) used this comparison, together with several other forms from central and 
southern Sulawesi meaning ‘move, spread, be common, well-known’, to propose __language__PAn__ *_laylay_ ‘spread, move, go around’, noting that [Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) had assigned the __language__Tagalog__ form to his *_DayDay_ ‘spread out’, “where it fits very poorly with __language__Javanese__ _ḍeḍe_ ‘sun oneself’.”  However, one must ask whether the comparison proposed by Mills is any more convincing than the one proposed by Dempwolff.
Borrowing from __language__Malay__, or a late innovation in Borneo.
The __language__Fijian__ and __language__Samoan__ forms are assumed to be related; the similarity of the __language__Acehnese__ form to these is due to chance.

On the basis of this comparison [Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) proposed Uraustronesisch *la(m)bas ‘stand open’ (_öffenstehen_).  It seems much better treated as a product of borrowing (__language__Toba Batak__ from __language__Malay__) and chance (the rest).
[Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) proposed this comparison, which seems to be a product of chance.

Although this comparison was accepted in [Blust (1989)](Source#cldf:blust1989) it now appears to be arbitrary, since __language__Nggela__ _aŋo_ shows parallel sound correspondences and a generic semantic similarity to several forms in non-__language__OC__ languages. For a general discussion of the word family *_qaŋ-_ meaning 'stench' cf. [Blust (1988:60ff)](Source#cldf:blust1988).
Probably a product of chance.  [Dempwolff (1934-1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) reconstructed ‘Uraustronesisch’ *_maniŋ_ ‘still, yet (additive)’
Chance. __language__Ngadha__ _beŋu_ probably is connected with __language__Manggarai__ _beŋur_ 'odor of something rotten', _beŋus_ 'rotten (of smell)' or _beŋut_ 'somewhat rotten (of a gourd, etc.).

[Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) cites this comparison, but I find nothing like the __language__Tagalog__ form in any modern dictionary of the language (it is more likely to be _káhig_ ‘scratch up the soil, as a fowl’).  [Zorc (1971)](Source#cldf:zorc1971) cites this for __language__PPh__ with the meaning ‘fire’, but so far as I have been able to determine it is entirely without support.
The New Ireland forms are related; their resemblance to the similar items in Taiwan
Chance. For the source of __language__Malagasy__ _áfitra_ cf. *_ampet_.

On the basis of the __language__Malay__ and __language__Malagasy__ forms [Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) proposed *panca(rR) ‘stream of water’ (_Wasserstrahl_), but until a better comparison is available this one, even with the addition of __language__Isneg__ _pásag_, is best treated as a product of convergence.
[Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) reconstructed *_kuju(r)_ ‘stretch out’, but there is little to distinguish this from a chance resemblance.

Proposed by [Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) as ‘sharp tasting’.  The __language__Ngaju Dayak__ form probably is borrowed from __language__Banjarese__, and the similarity of these to the __language__Tagalog__ word is best attributed to chance.

Description: substance used in fermenting palm wine
Comment: Apart from __language__Toba Batak__ _raru_, which probably is a __language__Malay__ loanword, the other forms cited here appear to show a similarity to one another that is due to chance.  [Dempwolfff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) proposed Uraustronesisch *_laru_ ‘substance used to purify fermenting liquids’ (_Mittel zum Klären gärender Flüssigkeiten_).
Probably a convergent development.

__language__Makassarese__ _boyoŋ_ appears to be a loan from __language__Malay__. The resemblance of the other forms both to this word and to one another is regarded as a product of chance, although the sequence _-VyV-_ is known to be symbolic of swinging or swaying movement in other morphemes ([Blust 1988:57-58](Source#cldf:blust1988)).

Based on this set of data Dempwolff posited *_bayaŋ_ ‘sway’, but the resemblance between these forms is best attributed to chance.  As noted in [Blust (1988:57-58)](Source#cldf:blust1988), medial _–y-_ is common in morphemes meaning ‘swing, sway, vacillate’ and the like.
[Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) used this proposed etymology to posit ‘Uraustronesisch’ *_luRut_ ‘to take out’ (_herausnehmen_), but his comparison appears fanciful.

Through a number of arbitrary morpheme cuts, proposed to isolate *_anzaŋ_ as a doublet of *_panzaŋ_ 'long, tall'. However, the forms cited here, together with __language__Kelabit__ _kadaŋ_ 'long', __language__Lampung__ _tijjaŋ_ 'long' suggest a collection of non-cognate forms related by a common monosyllabic 'root' ([Blust 1988](Source#cldf:blust1988)).
The resemblance of __language__Kowiai/Koiwai__ _et_ to the __language__Micronesian__ forms cited here is attributed to chance.
[Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) reconstructed ‘Uraustronesisch’ *_tes_ ‘to tear’.

[Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) reconstructed *_simbat_ ‘temporary aid’, but there is little evidence for this form apart from the two languages that he used as support, and the first vowel of the __language__Toba Batak__ form is irregular.  Although borrowing from __language__Javanese__ into __language__Toba Batak__ without passing through the medium of __language__Malay__ is virtually unknown, it seems best to treat this as a loan distribution pending the collection of a more convincing cognate set.

__language__Malay__ _lemuk_, cited by [Dempwolff](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438), does not appear in any source I have been able to consult.  The remaining part of this comparison is best considered unconnected.  [Dempwolff 
(1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) reconstructed Uraustronesisch *_lemuk_ ‘weak’.
The __language__KALL__ and __language__Manobo (Dibabawon)__ forms reflect earlier *_suyaq_. The similarity of __language__Thao__ _huya_ to these words is attributed to chance.
Chance. These forms may each contain a reflex of *_ia_ '3sg.'.

Chance. [Dempwolff (1934-38)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) cites this comparison under *_ikut_ 'theft', but I have been unable to find the __language__Tagalog__ form, and for __language__Javanese__ I find only _ikut_ 'take away'.

The __language__Iban__ and __language__Malay__ forms are cognate; the __language__Balinese__ and __language__Sasak__ forms probably are __language__Malay__ loans, and the similarity of __language__Puyuma__ _Hau_ to all of these is a product of chance.

Based on this comparison [Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) positted *_saka_ ‘to till the soil’.  However, this reconstruction has multiple problems, and the similarity of the forms compared now seems best attributed to chance.  [English (1986)](Source#cldf:english1986) gives __language__Tagalog__ _sáka_ as a borrowing of Spanish _saca_ ‘taking out, extraction; exportation’, which seems equally questionable, but none of the other meanings appear to be connected in any obvious way.

Chance. This comparison is an intriguing example of how a spurious etymology can be manufactured and perpetuated by competent comparative linguists despite a telling lack of credentials. [Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) glossed the __language__Tagalog__ form 'tortured' and the __language__Tongan__ form 'torture'. Although he rejected the phonologically irregular __language__Samoan__ form, [Dyen (1953)](Source#cldf:dyen1953) otherwise accepted Dempwolff's comparison unchanged, including his glosses for __language__Tagalog__ _inís_ and __language__Tongan__ _ino_. Neither Dempwolff's own sources ([Laktaw 1914](Source#cldf:laktaw1914) for Tagalog, [Colomb 1890](bib-Colomb) for __language__Tongan__) nor reliable alternatives of more recent date ([Panganiban 1973](Source#cldf:panganiban1973) for __language__Tagalog__, [Churchward 1959](Source#cldf:churchward1959) for __language__Tongan__), however, support the discrepant glosses cited in [Dempwolff (1934-38)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438).

[Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) reconstructed *_seru_ ‘trap’.  However, __language__Tagalog__ _síloɁ_ reflects __language__PPh__ *_siluq_ ‘noose, snare; net, and is therefore phonologically incompatible with the other forms in this comparison, which are also phonologically incompatible with one another.
__language__Casiguran Dumagat__ _bílao_ probably is a __language__Tagalog__ loan. The resemblance of the __language__Isneg__ word to these forms is attributed to chance.
Chance. For the etymology of the __language__Batak__ forms cf. *_qabaŋ qabaŋ_ 'float'.
Chance, __language__Ngadha__ _vala_ is assumed to be cognate with __language__Manggarai__ _balak_ 'tree sp.: _Scindapsis_, _Rhaphidophora_'.
The forms in __language__Gedaged__ and __language__Gitua__ are cognate. The similarity of these words to those in __language__LAKA__ and Lau is attributed to chance.

The __language__Sulawesian__ forms from __language__Bare'e__ to __language__Wolio__ are assumed to form one geographically and genetically restricted cognate set. The resemblance of the members of this set to the other forms cited here is attributed to chance.

It is tempting to consider __language__Hanunóo__ _buybúy_ a loan from one of the languages of northern Mindoro, and so recognize a __language__PPh__ *_buRbuR_ 'silk cotton tree: _Ceiba pentandra_'. However, this hypothesis fails to account for the appearance of a palatal glide in the __language__Tagalog__ and __language__Aklanon__ words without an implausible extension of the hypothesis to include these languages. The comparison thus appears to be a product of chance.
Chance. __language__Bimanese__ _βiβi_ probably reflects *_berber_ or *_birbir_.
__language__KOM__ _butéʔ_ is assumed to be a __language__Javanese__ loan. The resemblance of __language__Fijian__ _butō_ to these forms is attributed to chance.

[Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) posited *_kubay_ ‘vegetable’.  Despite its detailed coverage of flora, I have been unable to find __language__Malay__ _kubay_ (= _kubai_) in [Wilkinson (1959)](Source#cldf:wilkinson1959).

[Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) used this comparison (minus the __language__Wayan__ entry) to reconstruct *_sambaq_ (doublet (*_sembaq_) ‘reverence, adoration’.  However, the __language__Tagalog__ and __language__Malagasy__ words are clearly borrowings of __language__Malay__ _səmbah_ ‘obeisance; gesture of worship or homage; speech accompanied by such a gesture’, and the similarity of the __language__Wayan__ and __language__Fijian__ forms to these is best attributed to chance.

A __language__PSPh__ reconstruction *_balagen_ is possible, but the similarity of the __language__Proto-Minahasan__ and __language__Tae'__ forms to the others appears to be due to chance. Also cp. __language__Tiruray__ _berogon_ 'a wild vine: _Merremia peltata_'.
On the basis of this comparison [Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) posited ‘Uraustronesisch’ *_cahiŋ_ ‘viscous material’.
Chance. __language__Sangir__ _-ʔ_ can reflect any of a number of original final consonants.
The similarity of __language__Bontok__ _bágat_ to the other forms is due to chance. __language__Sundanese__, __language__Balinese__ _baga_ reflect a post-__language__PWMP__ innovation.

The forms in western Indonesia apart from __language__Ngaju Dayak__ _tantai_ are related, although some may be loans from __language__Malay__. __language__Tagalog__ _antáy_ and __language__Ngaju Dayak__ _tantai_ are assumed to resemble one another and the other forms cited here as a result of chance.

A late innovation in western Indonesia. Dempwolff's attempt to relate these forms to __language__Sa'a__ _maŋo_ 'breathe', __language__Tongan__ _ʔaŋoʔaŋo_ '(of a vessel which has had liquid in it, or the liquid itself) absolutely empty, absolutely dry', __language__Samoan__ _maŋo_ 'dry, dry up' (< *_ma-Raŋaw_) is unconvincing.

Chance.  [Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) posited ‘Uraustronesisch’ *_Teŋuk_ ‘to watch’ (_zuschauen_), but the __language__Malay__ form that he cites as təŋuk is given by [Wilkinson (1959)](Source#cldf:wilkinson1959) as 
__language__TEŊO__, with a non-corresponding mid-front vowel.  Even if this comparison could be justified, its extremely limited distribution among languages that are known to have been in an intense borrowing relationship for centuries would render it valueless as evidence for the lexicon of any early Austronesian proto-language.
[Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) reconstructed *_kemba_ ‘to be weak’.

[Dempwolff](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) compared the __language__Tagalog__, __language__Malay__ and __language__Javanese__ forms and posited Uraustronesisch *_lataq_ ‘weakness, debility, faintness’ (_Schwäche_).  However, to include __language__Tagalog__ _latáɁ_ in this comparison seems little short of absurd.  So far as we can determine from the evidence, then, this remarkable neurological/mental disorder, for which Java is famous among anthropologists, is a purely local development that may have originated in Java, where the extreme emphasis on courtesy and restraint may well trigger reactions in some individuals who carry an unconscious resentment of the social strictures under which they must live their lives.

__language__Bimanese__ _βunti_ and __language__Balinese__ _bunciŋ_ are assumed to be loans from __language__Makassarese__. The similarity of __language__Numfor__ _buk_ to these forms is attributed to chance.

This comparison, accepted in [Blust (1970)](Source#cldf:blust1970), is now rejected. The [Milke ](bib-Milke)reconstruction confuses __language__POc__ *_fafo_ 'to weed' with __language__POc__ *_wao_ 'forest and includes a __language__Motu__ word, _ava_, which is unrelated to either etymon. __language__POc__ *_fafo_, like __language__Maranao__ _wawaw_, derives from __language__PMP__ *_babaw_ 'to weed (a garden, etc.)'.
Chance. __language__Buginese__ _babbaʔ_ derives from *_balbal_ (q.v.).

[Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) used this comparison to posit *_saksak_ ‘white’, but I am unable to find any __language__Tagalog__ form of this shape and meaning, and all things considered, it is best forgotten.
Chance. __language__Toba Batak__ _buri_ is assigned to *_buRiq_ 'wash, as the hands'.

On the basis of this comparison [Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) posited Uraustronesisch *_pa(n)caŋ_ ‘piece of wood’.  The __language__Fijian__ form does not appear in [Capell (1957)](bib-Capell), and the whole set is best treated for now as a collection of unrelated forms.
Chance. [Dempwolff (1938)](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438) assigned the __language__Tagalog__ form to *_uDay_ 'worm', but his comparison does not appear to be justified.

One of [Dempwolff](Source#cldf:dempwolff193438)'s more problematic comparisons, __language__Toba Batak__ _aos_ appears to be a loanword from __language__Malay__, and the similarity of the __language__Tagalog__ and __language__Malagasy__ forms purely a matter of chance.

The __language__Hanunoo__, __language__Aklanon__ and __language__Cebuano__ forms reflect *_bejbej_, and __language__Palawan Batak__ _búdbud_ probably is a loan from a __language__Central Philippine__ reflex of the same form. The similarity of __language__Ifugaw__ _budbúd_ to these words is attributed to chance.

The middle morpheme of __language__Paiwan__ _si-tiav-an_ shows a perfect formal and semantic match with __language__Kavalan__ _siRab_, but the base form is __language__Paiwan__ _tiaw_ ‘day before or after today’, with regular morphophonemic alternation between _-w_ (< *_w_) and _v_, which normally reflects only *_b_.  Given this observation this comparison must be treated as a product of chance, despite its obvious appeal.  Why it is so similar to __language__PAn__ *_siRa_ ‘yesterday’ is unclear.

Description: to feel upset about s.t., brood over
rattan or bamboo strip used to measure, when weaving nets or baskets
Comment: This probably is not a Tagalog loan, as it refers to aspects of traditional culture that would have been universal among Austronesian speakers in the Philippines and many other places, and the Tagalog form lacks the specificity of the other glosses.

Description: to guide, direct the motion of someone or something, as a herd of animals
Comment: Possibly a Tagalog loan distribution, although the divergent semantics of the Ilokano form weighs against this interpretation.

Reflexes of PMP *musaŋ, originally reconstructed by Dempwolff (1938), are found from northern Luzon to western Flores, and so imply that a lexical distinction was made between two types of civet cat, most likely a larger and a smaller variety, as these are distinguished in some languages (cf. Manggarai _kula _‘civet cat’, _kula_ _mucaŋ_ ‘large male civet cat’).
PPH *buk(e)law, *lamun/lamut, and *sibáq ‘gluttonous’ referred to a runaway appetite for food; this term may have designated uncontrollable thirst.

Description: to catch someone or something that has escaped
Comment: Philippine reflexes of PAN *qusiR ‘pursuit, as of enemies or game’ refer to alien people or wild animals, but *aláw appears to refer to something formerly with the pursuer that has fled or escaped, and must be recaptured (the fleeing spirit of an ailing person, a domestic animal that has run off, etc). The Ilokano word refers to a traditional animistic healing ceremony of soul capture overlaid with a veneer of Christianity.

Quadrisyllabic comparisons that do not contain the *qali/kali- prefix are suspect, and if the heterorganic cluster in the reflexes was earlier separated by a schwa the base morpheme had an unprecedented five syllables. This may be a loan from a non-AN source, but no promising candidate has been found.

Description: mutual aid, as in farm work or house-building
Comment: This sparsely attested, but culturally important comparison, documents a practice that must have been all but universal in Neolithic societies, namely, the need for cooperative labor with work projects that everyone needed at some time, but no one could do alone, such as building a house, bringing in the harvest, and the like (as evidence that it extended beyond the Philippines, it is the national concept of _gotong royong_ (mutual aid) in Indonesia.
Possibly related to PAN *piliq ‘to choose, select’.
Ilokano_ ammól _is assumed to reflect *am-amul.

Description: type of wild vine used to blacken the teeth
Comment: With unexplained loss of the medial vowel in in Bikol and Hanunóo.

Description: dispute resolution; to resolve a dispute
share space or feelings with s.o, put oneself in another’s place
Comment: I assume regular reduction of VNC- clusters in the antepenult of native Maranao and Western Bukidnon Manobo words.

Description: to be upset, defensive or angry
to lay out flat, as a mat

Comment: This is a problematic comparison first proposed by Dempwolff (1938) as *gawa ‘to work’, which he distinguished from *gaway ‘magical activity’. The comparison given here supports the first of these reconstructions as *gawaq rather than *gawa, except that Iban shows final glottal stop for expected -_h_. The second appears here as PWMP *gaway ‘religious feast, festivity’. Complicating the picture are western Indonesian forms such as Sundanese _gawe_ ‘work, business’, _pa-gawe _‘worker’, Old Javanese _gaway ~ gawe_ ‘work, task, occupation; work, product; feast, celebration; use, purpose’, Balinese _gawe _‘to do, make, work’, and Sasak gawe ‘work, performance’ which suggest that *gaway may be an affixed form of *gawaq.
